fulltext: Police in Ontarioâ€™s Durham region confirmed they are investigating the conduct of a female officer who publicly expressed support for a trucker convoy protesting a Wuhan coronavirus vaccine mandate.Constable Erin Howard released a video this week in support of the estimated hundreds of truckers who are part of a convoy headed to Canadaâ€™s capital Ottawa from across the country to protest vaccine mandates enacted for travel across the border from the United States to Canada.â€œI wanted to give a shout out to all the truckers. I think what you guys are doing is incredible. Youâ€™re fighting for our rights and freedoms, and, right now,Â it feels like weâ€™re a little bit at war and those rights and freedoms are at stake,â€ said in the video posted to the social media platform Twitter on Monday.Supporting the truckers from one radio band to another ğŸ’™ #FreedomConvoy2022 pic.twitter.com/u6IzZSipTGâ€” EA (@erinhoward0118) January 24, 2022Durham Regional Police Service (DRPS) confirmed that it was investigating the actions of constable Howard, stating, â€œWe were made aware today of a video circulating on social media from one of our uniformed members regarding the Freedom Rally,â€ broadcaster CBC reports.â€œThe views expressed in that video do not reflect the views and opinions of DRPS. We are currently looking into this matter,â€ the DRPS added.Howard is also a member of the â€œPolice on Guardâ€ group, which is critical of vaccine mandates and lockdown restrictions and is said to have joined the group in May of last year.The group states that it is opposed to the emergency measures used by the government during the Wuhan coronavirus pandemic stating, â€œWe believe that these measures are not only in conflict with our Charter Oath but also place active duty police officers in an untenable position when directed by politicians and senior management to enforce these emergency measures.â€Millions Raised As Hundreds of Canadian Truckers Drive To Capital To Protest Vaccine Mandatehttps://t.co/PQVqeTKT6Uâ€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 25, 2022The Canadian trucker convoy, dubbed the â€œFreedom convoyâ€ has raised over 4.4 million Canadian dollars (Â£2.58 million/$3.48 million USD) as of Tuesday and is said to already involved hundreds of participants planning on arriving in Ottawa on Saturday.The vaccine mandate came into force for cross border travel into Canada on January 15th and affects as many as 26,000 truckers. The United States enacted the same policy to enter the country from Canada just days later on January 22nd.The protest also comes as Canada is facing supply chain disruptions across the country. Alberta conservative Premier Jason Kenney called for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to end the vaccine mandate for truckers saying, â€œNobody wants to see empty shelves and higher prices. We need some common sense here. Ottawa should drop the vax mandate for truckers now.â€Others, such as federal Conservative Party of Canada (CPC) leader Erin Oâ€™Toole have been more hesitant on the issue, with Mr Oâ€™Toole avoiding questions about the Freedom Convoy on Monday.A quarter of Canadians support putting unvaccinated people in jail, and two-thirds say they would support mandatory vaccinations. https://t.co/DwIKmO6tCTâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) January 21, 2022Despite the money raised for the convoy, a new poll released byÂ Nanos Research on Monday suggested that a majority of Canadians not only agree with vaccine mandates but 60 per cent support or somewhat support the idea of havingÂ unvaccinated people fined by the government.The poll comes after Quebec Premier Francois Legault announced he would be implementing a significant tax on the unvaccinated, which he termed as a â€œhealth contribution.â€Other polls have shown some Canadians to be even more radical in their views toward the unvaccinated, backing mandatory vaccines for children as young as five and around a quarter of Canadians supporting prison time for the unvaccinated.UNVAX TAX: Coming to a government near you https://t.co/U07tkW2Cq6â€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 12, 2022

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has labelled the anti-mandatory vaccination trucker convoy heading to Ottawa this weekend aâ€fringe minorityâ€ with â€œunacceptable views.â€Prime Minister Trudeau commented on the anti-vaccine trucker convoy, known as the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ at a press conference on Wednesday evening saying, â€œThe small fringe minority of people who are on their way to Ottawa, who are holding unacceptable views that they are expressing, do not represent the views of Canadians.â€â€œ(Canadians) who have been there for each other, who know that following the science and stepping up to protect each other is the best way to continue to ensure our freedoms, our rights, our values as a country,â€ Prime Minister Trudeau added, broadcaster Global News reports.Millions Raised As Hundreds of Canadian Truckers Drive To Capital To Protest Vaccine Mandatehttps://t.co/PQVqeTKT6Uâ€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 25, 2022Trudeau has previously stated his dislike for the unvaccinated telling a Candian French-language television programme, â€œThey donâ€™t believe in science/progress and are very often misogynistic and racist. Itâ€™s a very small group of people, but that doesnâ€™t shy away from the fact that they take up some space.â€â€œThis leads us, as a leader and as a country, to make a choice: Do we tolerate these people? Over 80% of the population of Quebec have done their duty by getting the shot. They are obviously not the issue in this situation,â€ he added.Canadian Cop Under Investigation Over Support For Anti-Vaccine Mandate Trucker Convoy https://t.co/9m0WzInNmQâ€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 26, 2022Wednesdayâ€™s comments come after Canadian mainstream media outlets such as Global News and CTV have painted many of the truck convoy participants as having links to â€œfar-right groups.â€The claim has been rejected byÂ Tamara Lich, one of the Freedom Convoy organisers who stated, â€œAs you know, we are on our way to Ottawa to hold a peaceful protest. I just want to put it out there that nobody in this convoy will be inciting violence or uttering threats. That is not what weâ€™re here to do.â€The allegations are not the first time Canadian politicians or media have equated those against lockdowns or vaccination policies to white nationalists or far-right extremists.Last year in March, former Calgary mayor Naheed Nenshi claimed that anti-mask and anti-lockdown protestors were extremists saying, â€œThose people at those anti-mask protests, letâ€™s not kid ourselves. Theyâ€™re not people who [are protesting because they] need to eat. They are people who are marching in thinly veiled white nationalist supremacist anti-government protests.â€Calgary MayorÂ Naheed Nenshi has claimed anti-lockdown protests in Canada are "thinly veiled white nationalist" activities. https://t.co/DacNYCmWDRâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) May 12, 2021So far, the Freedom Convoy, which urges the government to scrap vaccine mandates for truckers engaging in cross-border travel to the United States,Â  has raised over 6.8 million Canadian dollars (Â£4 million/$5.3 million USD) in less than two weeks as of Thursday.The exact numbers of participants in the convoy have been estimated from hundreds to thousands, with a Toronto Sun newspaper report claiming it took the convoy two hours to pass through the northern Ontario town of Dryden earlier this week.The truckers are expected to reach Canadaâ€™s capital Ottawa on Saturday but it is unlikely Prime Minister Trudeau will speak to the protestors as he has claimed that he will be isolating at home for the next five days after claiming to have been exposed to the coronavirus. Despite subsequently testing negative, he said he would still be going into isolation.The announcement led some on social media to accuse the Canadian Prime Minister of going into hiding ahead of the protest.A quarter of Canadians support putting unvaccinated people in jail, and two-thirds say they would support mandatory vaccinations. https://t.co/DwIKmO6tCTâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) January 21, 2022

During an appearance on FNCâ€™s â€œTucker Carlson Tonight,â€Â Freedom Convoy 2022 spokesman Benjamin Dichter highlighted protests in Canada against vaccine mandates led by the nationâ€™s trucking industry.Dichter warned this effort by Canadaâ€™s Trudeau government could be something coming to the United States.â€œItâ€™s simple,â€ he explained. â€œI mean, weâ€™ve seen Canada go from a country of Justin Trudeauâ€™s promises of sunny ways into dark, authoritarian oppression and control. We want to do â€” we want two things. We want to get rid of the vaccine mandates, and the passports and the passports is â€” thatâ€™s really the concerning one. Yesterday, it was my first time ever crossing the border in my truck with my digital passport, and I held my phone up to the Border agent to give them the QR code. You know what he said to me? â€˜Oh, itâ€™s okay. I donâ€™t need it.'â€â€œSo, what do you mean you donâ€™t need it?â€ Dichter continued. â€œHe says, â€˜Oh, your phone already popped up on my screen and is correlated with your passport?â€™ Can you think of that? Can you believe that? So they know everybody who is coming up to the border before theyâ€™re there, and they are tracking them. Now, maybe it is outlandish, but whatâ€™s to prevent the government from introducing that across Canada and not limiting it to just borders and you guys are getting it as well, and you can thank us for it because apparently, according to our sources, within the media, and within government, we have some close ties. Apparently, the Trudeau government â€” the Biden administration have no interest in it, but the Trudeau Government lobbied and requested the Biden administration to introduce this.â€â€œWe donâ€™t know why,â€ he added. â€œWe donâ€™t know the terms of the deal. Are they going to be trading Intelligence back and forth between Canada and the U.S. tracking cell phones? Of course, we have no idea. But this is where weâ€™re going if this does not stop. Thatâ€™s why this is the line. This is where it ends.â€Follow Jeff Poor on Twitter @jeff_poor

Former President Donald Trump on Saturday praised the â€œfreedom convoyâ€ of Canadian truckers protesting against Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeauâ€™s coronavirus health mandates.Trump said the truckers were doing more to defend freedom than some of Americaâ€™s elected officials. â€œThe Canadian truckers, youâ€™ve been reading about it, who are resisting bravely these lawless mandates are doing more to defend American freedom than our own leaders by far,â€ he said, speaking to a crowd in Conroe, Texas.Trump: â€œThe Canadian truckers, youâ€™ve been reading about it. Who are resisting bravely these lawless mandates are doing more to defend American freedom than our own leaders by far, and we want those  great Canadian truckers to know that we are with them all the way.â€ pic.twitter.com/DPAfraVHjdâ€” Ian Miles Cheong (@stillgray) January 30, 2022He made clear that he supports the convoyâ€™s movement, saying, â€œand we want those great Canadian truckers to know that we are with them all the way.â€The convoy of truckers has been traveling through Canada in recent days, making their way to the countryâ€™s capital city, Ottawa, on Saturday. As the convoy of thousands of truckers hit Ottawa on Saturday, Trudeau and his familyÂ fledÂ their home, citing â€œsafety concerns.â€TrudeauÂ attackedÂ the protesters, calling them a â€œsmall fringe minority of people,â€ who â€œdo not represent the views of Canadians.â€Trump also called on governments to move past pandemic-era health mandates at his Saturday night rally.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his family have reportedly fled their home in Ottawa for â€œa secret location,â€ as thousands of truckers traveling in a â€œfreedom convoyâ€ to protest vaccine mandates made their way to its capital city.Trudeau, who is in isolation after being exposed to coronavirus, left his home due to â€œsecurity concerns,â€ according to the CBC.â€œI learned that I have been exposed to COVID-19. My rapid test result was negative. I am following @OttawaHealth rules and isolating for five days. I feel fine and will be working from home,â€ TrudeauÂ tweetedÂ on Thursday. Social media users pointed out that his announcement came days before the trucker convoy hit Ottawa.Weird. I can't imagine anything rolling through Ottowa in a massive fucking line in the next 5 days that he'd want to avoid. https://t.co/bTw921EHXLâ€” RazÃ¶rFist (@RAZ0RFIST) January 27, 2022TrudeauÂ characterizedÂ the convoy as a â€œsmall fringe minorityâ€ and said they held â€œunacceptable viewsâ€ in the days leading up to Ottawaâ€™s Saturday protest.The Parliamentary Protective Service anticipated more than 10,000 people would be at the Ottawa protest.The truckers have been traveling in a convoy protesting the countryâ€™s vaccine mandates for several days. Last October, Trudeau implemented a vaccine mandate for federal workers. On January 15, he instituted a vaccine mandate for all crossing the Canadian border in a move impacting truckers. President Joe BidenÂ  implemented a similarÂ mandateÂ at the U.S. border earlier in the month.The Canadian Trucker Alliance, whichÂ estimatedÂ at least 12,000 drivers are not vaccinated, does not support the truckersâ€™ protest.If any American media has covered #OttawaConvoy #Ottowa #FreedomConvoy2022 I havenâ€™t seen it. It seems quite newsworthy pic.twitter.com/lk51EihWtDâ€” Phil Hollowayâ„¢ âš–ï¸ âœˆï¸ ğŸ˜ (@PhilHollowayEsq) January 29, 2022â€œItâ€™s not just about the vaccines. Itâ€™s about stopping the public health mandates altogether,â€Â saidÂ Daniel Bazinet, Valley Flatbed & Transportation owner in Nova Scotia.

Truckers in the Netherlands formed a convoy on Sunday to protest their nationâ€™s lockdown measures, following the lead of their fellow road hauliers in Canada.A convoy of trucks, tractors, and cars formed in Leeuwarden on Sunday to protest lockdown measures in the Netherlands.The Dutch convoy mimicks a major lockdown protest being held in Canada, where thousands have poured into the nationâ€™s capital of Ottowa to rally against vaccine mandates.According to a report byÂ Hart von Nederland, dozens of vehicles joined a convoy on Sunday morning in a way reminiscent of proceedings on the other side of the Atlantic, with those taking part demanding an end to lockdown restrictions supposedly aimed at curbing the Chinese Coronavirus.â€œIâ€™m going to ride as long as I can, because Iâ€™m tired of all the measures,â€ the publication reports one protester as saying. â€œFreedom, thatâ€™s what itâ€™s all about, freedom!â€â€œWe are against the corona measures of the current cabinet and that is why we will soon go on a parade through Friesland,â€ said another woman who planned on taking part in the convoy. â€œSitting at home on the couch makes no sense and that is why it is good that we now letâ€™s all know for once; enough is enough.â€Dutch Cafes, Restaurants, Shops Defy Govt, Open in Protest Against Lockdownhttps://t.co/Ra1fkxVk3râ€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 15, 2022The Dutch protest, according toÂ De Telegraaf,Â was inspired by events in Canada, where thousands of truckers have joined a â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ demanding an end to vaccine mandates in the country.It is expected that over 10,000 protesters will attend the weekend-long rally against the measures in the Canadian capital of Ottowa.Meanwhile, the nationâ€™s Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau, has come under fire for reportedly fleeing his home in the run-up to the protest, with â€œsecurity concernsâ€ being cited as the reason for the move.The Liberal Party PM had previously denounced the truckers as a â€œsmall fringe minorityâ€ who held â€œunacceptable viewsâ€.Former US President Donald Trump however has praised the truckers, saying that they were doing more to defend â€œAmerican freedomâ€ than the leaders of the United States.â€œThe Canadian truckers â€” youâ€™ve been reading about it â€” who are resisting bravely these lawless mandates are doing more to defend American freedom than our own leaders by far and we want those great Canadian truckers to know that we are with them all the way,â€ the 45th President of the United States said during a rally on Saturday.Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his family have reportedly fled their home in Ottawa for â€œa secret location,â€ as thousands of truckers traveling in a â€œfreedom convoyâ€ to protest vaccine mandates made their way to its capital city. https://t.co/ZMKF6EEw8zâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) January 30, 2022

Ezra Levant, the founder of Canadaâ€™s conservative Rebel News network, gave a stirring address Saturday in the countryâ€™s capital, Ottawa, as a massive convoy of trucks protesting vaccine mandates arrived at Parliament Hill to register their dissent.The convoy, which began a week ago, became a global sensation andÂ raised millions of dollars to support truckers as they oppose U.S. and Canadian mandates requiring that truckers crossing the U.S.-Canada border show proof of vaccination.Levant, speaking amid the din of horns and bells, was welcomed by the crowd, and gave a short but powerful address.He began by talking about the media bias against conservatives, and against the truckers and their cause: â€œWhen people say, what do we do about the media, we become the media. â€¦ Youâ€™ve got to tell the story yourselves.â€â€œThe government says youâ€™re racist, the government says youâ€™re sexist, the government says youâ€™re violent. In the meantime, Iâ€™ve never seen a more diverse group of Canadians,â€ he said, to rousing cheers. â€œFar from violent, people want to not be violated anymore. [Prime Minister] Justin Trudeau says youâ€™re extreme, but heâ€™s the one who has violated our civil rights.â€œHe says youâ€™re a fringe. Well, thatâ€™s a pretty bloody big fringe.â€I was invited by the truckers to give a short speech. Hereâ€™s what I said:  pic.twitter.com/ZYclZwDBtHâ€” Ezra Levant ğŸ (@ezralevant) January 29, 2022Levant predicted that Trudeau would cling to power, despite the convoy. Still, the protest would not be in vain: â€œLet me tell you what I think the point is: The point is the convoy itself, to show that youâ€™re not alone, to show that youâ€™re not the crazy one, they are. TO show that youâ€™re not the un-Canadian one, they are. You already achieved your goal by being here.â€Former President Donald Trump praised the â€œfreedom convoyâ€ in a speech at a rally in Texas on Saturday:Â â€œThe Canadian truckers, youâ€™ve been reading about it, who are resisting bravely these lawless mandates are doing more to defend American freedom than our own leaders by far. â€¦ [W]e want those great Canadian truckers to know that we are with them all the way.â€Joel B. Pollak is Senior Editor-at-Large at Breitbart News and the host of Breitbart News Sunday on Sirius XM Patriot on Sunday evenings from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. ET (4 p.m. to 7 p.m. PT). Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Monday he has contracted coronavirus. The revelation came barely 24-hours after heÂ and his family left their home in Ottawa for a secret location, citing security concerns as massive trucker convoys surged into the capital to protest vaccine mandates.Trudeau used social media to inform the world of his condition. No announcement has been made as to when he is likely to appear in public again.â€œIâ€™m feeling fine â€” and Iâ€™ll continue to work remotely this week while following public health guidelines. Everyone, please get vaccinated and get boosted,â€ Trudeau tweeted.This morning, I tested positive for COVID-19. Iâ€™m feeling fine â€“ and Iâ€™ll continue to work remotely this week while following public health guidelines. Everyone, please get vaccinated and get boosted.â€” Justin Trudeau (@JustinTrudeau) January 31, 2022He has been in isolation since last Wednesday when he said that heâ€™d had a positive contact.As Breitbart News reported, last week Trudeau dismissed the convoys of truck drivers as angry, isolated loners on the fringe of society.Trudeau commented on the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ at a press conference on Wednesday evening saying, â€œThe small fringe minority of people who are on their way to Ottawa, who are holding unacceptable views that they are expressing, do not represent the views of Canadians.â€Supporters of the Freedom Convoy protest Covid-19 vaccine mandates and restrictions on January 29, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. (DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)â€œ(Canadians) who have been there for each other, who know that following the science and stepping up to protect each other is the best way to continue to ensure our freedoms, our rights, our values as a country,â€ Trudeau added.He spoke even as convoy members were able to raise millions of dollars to aid their cause and fight the governmentâ€™s coronavirus vaccine mandates.Millions Raised As Hundreds of Canadian Truckers Drive To Capital To Protest Vaccine Mandatehttps://t.co/PQVqeTKT6Uâ€” Breitbart London (@BreitbartLondon) January 25, 2022On Sunday, photos and video poured swamped social media revealing the truckers forming in protest at the countryâ€™s vaccine mandate had a tremendous amount of support from Canadians of all walks of life.Thousands of those supporters took to the nationâ€™s frozen streets well into the dark of night in solidarity with the grass roots movement.

Australian truckers used social media over the weekend to plan their own â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ similar to the one in Canada, telling supporters they should â€œswarm to Canberra to protest mandates and restrictionsâ€ on Monday. A GoFundMe page for the convoy was frozen after raising over $160,000 to support the cause.Truckies set to swarm to Canberra to protest mandates and restrictions.https://t.co/AiUFhKccrAâ€” Avi Yemini (@OzraeliAvi) January 29, 2022Images shared on Telegram of the convoy bound for Canberra today. pic.twitter.com/NKtvIEZ6GIâ€” Daniel James Dulhunty (@dulhunty) January 31, 2022Trucking website Big Rigs noted on Sunday that judging by social media posts, the â€œvast majorityâ€ of Australiaâ€™s â€œtruckiesâ€ are â€œdouble-vaxxed and have diligently complied with health orders for the last couple of years.â€ Only a â€œsmall minorityâ€ of posts related to the protest appeared to come from professional truck drivers.Big Rigs quoted Australiaâ€™s National Road Freighters Association expressing concerns with how a massive convoy would affect Canberraâ€™s traffic and infrastructure, particularly the service and rest areas dedicated to truckers.Anti-vaccine mandate protesters are on their way to Australia's capital as part of the 'Canberra Convoy', inspired by recent Canadian rallies, but there's already confusion within the group. #auspol pic.twitter.com/baU4io5XMbâ€” 10 News First (@10NewsFirst) January 31, 2022The GoFundMe page for Australiaâ€™s convoy was launched by an anonymous individual called â€œIronbark Thunderbolt.â€ According to the page, all of the funds raised would be given to an individual named James Greer, identified by Australiaâ€™s ABC News as a â€œdoomsday prepperâ€ who planned to drive a camper to Canberra.â€œMoney will be withdrawn into Jamesâ€™ account and the team will gather receipts and information from those in need for reimbursement or transfer. Transfers will then be made directly to the people in need. Our lawful team are happy to deal with any discrepancies,â€ the fundraising page said.Both media outlets and GoFundMe managers asked for more details about these financial arrangements, but there was no public response from either Greer or â€œIronbark Thunderbolt.â€ According to ABC News, some convoy participants used Facebook to voice â€œconfusion and frustrationâ€ with their inability to collect reimbursement for their expenses from the GoFundMe account as promised.On Monday, GoFundMe froze the $160,000 raised by the campaign until its creator â€œcompletes the verification process, and is able to provide documentation to our team about how funds will be distributed.â€A GoFundMe spokesperson later warned that â€œfundraisers raising money to promote misinformation about vaccines violate GoFundMeâ€™s terms of service and will be removed.â€The demonstration, variously billed as â€œMillions March Against Mandatory Vaccinationâ€ and â€œThe 2022 Official Convoy to Canberra Terra Australis,â€ produced a crowd of about 800 demonstrators who marched from Canberraâ€™s Federation Mall to Parliament House, where they held a rally, listened to speeches, sang defiant songs, and demanded to speak with a parliamentary representative. The crowd drew close enough to the Parliament building to make Australian Federal Police nervous, even though the legislature will not be in session until next week. Some attendees told ABC News they planned to camp on the lawn until Parliament was in session.The Canberra Times described the scene on Monday:Protesters were seen waving the red ensign flag, flags in support of Donald Trump, the Canadian flag and the Knights Templar flag.Australian red ensign flags â€“ which is the same as the Australian flag but for the color â€“ has been co-opted by self-described â€˜sovereign citizensâ€™. Regional governments in Canada have begun announcing plans to drop onerous civil rights restrictions on their citizens meant to contain the Chinese coronavirus this week following mounting pressure from national protests, most prominently the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ in Ottawa.The â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ initially led by truckers but now a movement of thousands of people, arrived in the national capital this weekend demanding an end to lockdowns, business restrictions, mask mandates, vaccine mandates, and other restrictions in effect as a result of the pandemic. Protesters have vowed to remain in the capital until the government of far-left Prime Minister Justin Trudeau lifts all such restrictions. Trudeau is currently in an undisclosed location recovering from an alleged coronavirus infection but has issued remarks from that location dismissing the protesters as racist, violent â€œtinfoil hatâ€ wearers.Local police disagree. While Ottawa Police Chief Peter Sloly warned this week that â€œall options are on the tableâ€ to end the protests, he admitted that authorities had not documented any incidents of violence.â€œIt could have led to significant and severe injuries, and it could have led to the loss of life. None of that has occurred over the last four days,â€ Sloly said on Monday.On Monday,Â Quebec Premier FranÃ§ois Legault was the first to announce changes to coronavirus policies since a weekend of widespread peaceful protests in the capital. Legault walked back a plan to implement an extra tax on individuals who have not received doses of a Chinese coronavirus vaccination product. The initial plan was to tax unvaccinated people at higher rates on the grounds that they would allegedly be a burden to the government healthcare system because they would contract more severe cases of Chinese coronavirus. The tax would have forced its victims to pay up to $800 Canadian dollars, or about $630 USD.Quebec Prime Minister Francois Legault takes part during a press conference with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on the airline industry in Montreal, Quebec on July 15, 2021. â€“ The funding announcement, towards greener aeronautic companies and electric aeronautics, was done in conjunction with the Quebec Prime Minister FranÃ§ois Legault, and various company CEOs, such as CAE and Pratt and Whitney Canada. (Photo by Andrej Ivanov/AFP via Getty Images)â€œI understand this divides Quebecers,â€ an apologetic Legault said on Tuesday. â€œItâ€™s time to work together.â€Canadaâ€™sÂ Global and Mail noted in its coverage of Quebec scrapping the plan that the tax would have â€œraised legal and logistical issuesâ€ that may have resulted in it never being implemented at all. The plan had prompted nationwide outrage, which Legault acknowledged in his remarks, stating that he hoped to â€œrebuild bridgesâ€ with those offended.At least four other Canadian provinces have announced either an end to vaccine-related travel restrictions or at least a plan to come up with an exit strategy for the current status quo this week. Saskatchewan, one of the provinces with milder restrictions, announced that the â€œvaccine passportâ€ program would not continue in place past February. Premier Scott Moe told reporters that he did not believe coronavirus vaccines were making any significant difference in containing the spread of the virus, noting that both he and Trudeau were fully vaccinated when they tested positive.â€œItâ€™s quite obvious that the virus itself has adapted through Omicron and transmits among vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals quite freely,â€ Moe asserted.The premier also cited public dissatisfaction with the policies as a reason to get rid of them.â€œPeople are asking their government for a return to normal, a removal of public health restrictions,â€ he said.â€œAt present, all Saskatchewan residents must show proof that they have received two shots of the COVID-19 [Chinese coronavirus] vaccine to enter restaurants, bars, and other businesses. They also have the option to provide a negative COVID-19 test,â€ the CBC noted.Alberta, home to one of the largest anti-mandate protests in the country, issued a similar announcement, but its premier promised only the partial removal of restrictions.â€œOnce we begin to see a sustained reduction in COVID pressure on the hospitals, I am looking forward to being able to make decisions about moving toward relaxation of public health measures at that time,â€ Premier Jason Kenney said on Tuesday. â€œI believe that will happen this month.â€Kenney explicitly mentioned frustrations regarding vaccine mandates imposed on truck drivers.â€œThe restriction on unvaccinated truck drivers doesnâ€™t make sense and itâ€™s going to further force up food prices and create challenges for supplies, including food,â€ Kenney said, indicating that a recent visit to Washington was precisely meant to encourage the United States to drop such limitations on Canadians.Truckers and allied protesters have blocked the border between Alberta and the United States in Coutts, a border municipality, and refused to leave. This protest is an extension of the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ in Ottawa. Reports indicate that local companies have refused to tow away the protesters, complicating law enforcement attempts to end the assembly.The governments of British Columbia and Manitoba have also issuedÂ similar but more cautious remarks indicating optimism that restrictions on free movement were weeks away from ending.A poll released on Monday by the Angus Reid Institute found that a plurality of Canadians agrees with the goal of the protests â€“ to end the restrictions on individual rights in the name of public health. About 54 percent of respondents agreed with repealing all mandates, a 15-percent increase from the results of the same poll at the beginning of the month.Follow Frances Martel onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter.

Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) have confirmed to Breitbart News that no officers have been assaulted by protesters at the Alberta border blockade despite the assertion from the provinceâ€™s Premier, Jason Kenney, that they had.The blockade â€“ in which truckers protesting various Canadian coronavirus mandates by blocking the highway used as an international border crossing between Coutts, Alberta, and Sweet Grass, Montana â€“ is part of what has become known as the â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ which also has conducted large demonstrations in Ottawa, the nationâ€™s capital.Supporters of the Freedom Convoy protest Covid-19 vaccine mandates and restrictions on January 29, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. â€“ Hundreds of truckers drove their giant rigs into the Canadian capital Ottawa on Saturday as part of a self-titled â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ to protest vaccine mandates required to cross the US border. (Photo by Dave Chan / AFP) (Photo by DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)At a press conference Tuesday, Kenney called for â€œcalmâ€ and said that he had heard reports of â€œpeople allied with the protesters assaulting RCMP officers, including one instance trying to ram members of the RCMP [with a vehicle].â€â€œThis kind of conduct is totally unacceptable,â€ Kenney continued. â€œAssaulting law enforcement officers who were simply doing their job to maintain public safety and the rule of law is completely unacceptable.â€RCMP Cpl. Curtis Peters, who is on the ground in Coutts, independently confirmed to Breitbart News that no such assault took place, and the incident with the vehicle was an accident that occurred between civilians.â€œThere were no RCMP officers assaulted,â€ he said. â€œThere was an assault that took place between two civilians. One of them was a protester who had been traveling the wrong way on a one-way lane of highway and then got in a collision with the innocent person. â€¦Â But we havenâ€™t had any assaults of police.â€According to Peters, the collision caused a fight to break out between the drivers.While Kenney said that the protesters have â€œrefused to negotiate in good faith with the RCMP,â€ Peters told Breitbart News that communications have been â€œconstantâ€ and â€œongoing.â€Peters said the RCMPâ€™s goal is to peaceably â€œbring this around to opening the roadway,â€ and added that in the past several hours, the truckers had agreed to open one lane of traffic for the northbound and southbound access. â€œBut that wasnâ€™t really opening up the border and bringing vehicles down, it just sort of allowed some more people to leave that had originally taken part in the protests and wanted out. That was done on their own accord,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™ve been told that might be a temporary thing.â€In the negotiations, the truckers are maintaining that unless all the mandates are dropped, they are not leaving.While â€œnobodyâ€™s been seriously hurt,â€ Peters said, â€œthereâ€™s still conflict.â€One such instance of conflict has to do with Coutts Mayor Jim Willett, who has reported harassment from some supporters of the protest.According to Peters, Willett â€” who represents a town of 245 persons as of Canadaâ€™s last published census â€” said he has protesters outside his residence harassing him.â€œThe fight isnâ€™t with the mayor,â€ Peters said. â€œHe has no stake in the game when it comes to mandates. Heâ€™s trying to keep this community trucking along.â€The RCMP has also been tracking online threats to the mayor, but could not confirm to Breitbart News that those threats were coming from protesters.Peters says he cannot predict when an end to the blockade, which entered its fifth day Wednesday, will come.Breccan F. None of that has occurred over the last four days,â€ SlolyÂ toldÂ reporters.At the same press event, the mayor of Ottawa, Jim Watson, promised that his government was â€œdoing everything possible to bring this to an end peacefully.â€The protests are referred to as the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ because they have been led nationwide by convoys of truckers, who have been among the most vocal in opposing vaccine mandates to travel across Canadian provinces given the nature of their world. Former President Donald Trump showed support for the â€œfreedom convoyâ€ of truckers protesting vaccine mandates for the second time in one week.The former President said in a statement:The Freedom Convoy is peacefully protesting the harsh policies of far left lunatic Justin Trudeau who has destroyed Canada with insane Covid mandates. UPDATE: Following the publication of this article and an intense backlash against the company, GoFundMe has announced that all donors to the fundraiser for the Canadian Freedom Convoy will be â€œautomaticallyâ€ refunded. Donors can expect to see refunds within 7-10 business days.â€” GoFundMe (@gofundme) February 5, 2022The update we issued earlier enabled all donors to get a refund and outlined a plan to distribute remaining funds to verified charities selected by the Freedom Convoy organizers. However, due to donor feedback, we are simplifying the process and automatically refunding donations.â€” GoFundMe (@gofundme) February 5, 2022The original story continues below:In what is likely to go down in history as one of the most brazen actions ever taken by a Big Tech platform, money sent by small donors to the Freedom Convoy will be redirected to causes that the donors never intended to support, unless they request a refund before February 19.Supporters of the Freedom Convoy protest Covid-19 vaccine mandates and restrictions in front of Parliament on January 29, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. â€“ Hundreds of truckers drove their giant rigs into the Canadian capital Ottawa on Saturday as part of a self-titled â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ to protest vaccine mandates required to cross the US border. (Photo by LARS HAGBERG/AFP via Getty Images)It is the latest in a long line of politically biased decisions by the platform which has driven many conservative activists to alternative platforms, such as the Christian-owned competitor GiveSendGo.Via GoFundMe:Given how this situation has evolved, no further funds will be directly distributed to the Freedom Convoy organizers â€”Â we will work with organizers to send all remaining funds to credible and established charities chosen by the Freedom Convoy 2022 organizers and verified by GoFundMe.All donors may submit a request for a full refund until February 19th, 2022Â using this dedicated refund form.The Freedom Convoy, which was created by Canadian truckers to protest draconian coronavirus restrictions in the country, has captured attention around the world.Galvanized by their effective, peaceful resistance against two years of government restrictions on everyday activities, people around the world pledged over $10 million in small donations to the Canadian truckers through GoFundMe.But, because the fundraiser was held on a far-left platform known for shutting down fundraisers and even freezing funds destined for causes popular with conservatives, a large portion of that money (maybe even most of it, if donors arenâ€™t alerted to the situation, and the refund deadline) is likely to be redirected to causes and charities that are vetted by GoFundMe.The same platform that allows users to solicit donations for violent BLM-supporting felons who assaulted police officers says it took the decision because of â€œpolice reports of violence and other unlawful activity.â€GoFundMeâ€™s decision to effectively steal the funds was welcomed by the Ottawa police and by the cityâ€™s left-wing mayor, Jim Watson.We want to thank @gofundme for listening to our concerns as a City and a police service. The decision to withhold funding for these unlawful demonstrations is an important step and we call on all crowdfunding sites to follow.â€” Ottawa Police (@OttawaPolice) February 5, 2022NEW:I want to sincerely thank the team at @gofundme for listening to the plea made by the City and the Ottawa Police to no longer provide funds to the convoy organizers. 1/3â€” Jim Watson (@JimWatsonOttawa) February 4, 2022The move drew political condemnation from across the border. Arizona senate candidate and former venture capitalist Blake Masters said GoFundMe executives should be arrested for â€œfraud and theftâ€ if the money is sent to left-wing nonprofits.If GoFundMe steals the truckersâ€™ money & sends it to left-wing non-profits, the companyâ€™s executives should be arrested and tried for fraud and theft.â€” Blake Masters (@bgmasters) February 5, 2022GoFundMe has a long history of bias, including banning a legal fundraiser for Kyle Rittenhouse before the teenager, now cleared of all charges,was ever convicted of a crime.The platform also banned a fundraiser for a Texas nurse seeking to overturn an employee vaccine mandate, an election integrity project launched shortly after the 2020 election, and a fundraiser launched by conservative commentator Candace Owens for a cafÃ© owner who criticized George Floyd and BLM protesters during the 2020 summer riots.Update â€”Â Following the publication of this article, GoFundMe announced that it would refund all donors to the Freedom Convoy instead of â€œredirectingâ€ their donations. The story has been updated with this information.Allum Bokhari is the senior technology correspondent at Breitbart News.Â He is the author ofÂ #DELETED: Big Techâ€™s Battle to Erase the Trump Movement and Steal The Election.

Candice Bergen, elected on Wednesday to replace the ousted Erin Oâ€™Toole as interim leader of the Canadian Conservative caucus, came out swinging in her debut House of Commons appearance by blasting Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for refusing to extend an â€œolive branchâ€ to Freedom Convoy demonstrators. Montreal Mayor Valerie Plante on Sunday asked the Quebec government to provide a detailed plan for â€œreopeningâ€ the province as it emerges from strict coronavirus emergency measures. Ottawa police detained and brutalized a 78-year-old man identified as Gerry Charlebois on Monday for violating the ban imposed that day on honking car horns. Police appear in multiple videos twisting the elderly manâ€™s arm around his back and shoving him into the side of a car.The arrest took place amid attempts to crack down on a trucker-led protest in Canadaâ€™s capital dubbed the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ demanding an end to civil rights abuses by the Canadian government in the name of stopping the spread of Chinese coronavirus, including vaccine and mask mandates and business shutdowns. Over a week into the protest, the assembly has remained largely peaceful and manifested largely through incessant truck honking. A local court granted an injunction that bans any car honking in the city for ten days on Monday.The images of police battering Carlebois are particularly striking given his small size â€“Â Carleboisâ€™s familyÂ toldÂ theÂ Toronto Sun on Monday that he is 4â€™10â€ â€“ and the fact that the mandates the Freedom Convoy is protesting are ostensibly meant to protect people more vulnerable to severe coronavirus infections, like the elderly.I spoke with him. Heâ€™s in pain. Heâ€™s 4 foot 10. A retired janitor with 11 grandkids, 4 great grandkids. If this disgraceful treatment of a 78 year old for honking his horn and a thumbs up to a trucker is acceptable to @JustinTrudeau @fordnation @JimWatsonOttawa no one is safe. https://t.co/DBgPLpCquXâ€” Joe Warmington (@joe_warmington) February 8, 2022Speaking to theÂ Sunâ€˜s Joe Warmington, Charlebois confirmed the incident and explained that he was not a protester or engaged in any disruptive activity. He is vaccinated. He has no criminal record and was â€œconfusedâ€ as to why police would stop him for honking a horn; the court had just banned such an action within hours of the detention. Charlebois told Warmington that he wanted to go to the downtown neighborhood to â€œlook at the trucksâ€ but did not walk into the protest site specifically because he thought it may be dangerous. â€œI decided it was too much so I just looked from the van and then started to head home.â€In the time in which he was preparing to head home, a truck drove past, to which he offered â€œa thumbs up and a honk.â€ Police then battered him in response to the honk.Warmington reported that Charlebois has suffered several cuts, bruises, and aches as a result of the attack. His sons, who also spoke to theÂ Sun, said that Charlebois may need to visit the hospital to ensure that he does not have any long-term injuries, as he cannot move his arm properly and now has a â€œvery messed-up shoulder.â€Police had not yet commented on the incident at press time.I have put request to â¦@OttawaPoliceâ© â¦@JimWatsonOttawaâ© â¦@OPSChiefSlolyâ© To verify a video that shows an elderly man being taken to ground and handcuffed and taken away. And for any witnesses pic.twitter.com/3iUBG9S4Moâ€” Joe Warmington (@joe_warmington) February 7, 2022Ottawa police announced on Sunday, prior to the injunction passing, that authorities had arrested seven people within a 24-hour window and opened â€œover 60 criminal investigationsâ€ â€“ small numbers given the thousands attending the protests â€“ and conceded that most of those investigations were for â€œmischief, thefts, hate crimes and property damage.â€ Six of the seven arrests on Sunday were on charges of â€œmischief.â€The relatively minor police action â€“ and the victims of said action, like Charlebois â€“ contrast with the image of the protesters that leftist Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has attempted to cultivate. Discussing the protesters during a last-minute visit to Parliament on Monday, Trudeau repeatedly accused the protesters of displaying â€œswastikas.â€ He has in the past equated distrust of coronavirus vaccine products with racism and misogyny. More recently, he referred to mandate opponents as wearers of â€œtinfoil hats.â€Trudeau has taken a less hard line against the protesters than Ottawa Police Chief Peter Sloly, however, who has threatened to dislodge the honking truckers by any means necessary.â€œAll options are on the table, from negotiation through to enforcement,â€ Sloly said of removing the protesters last week. Trudeau has personally intervened to remove both options mentioned, refusing to meet with or address protestersâ€™ concerns in any way, but also asserting that military intervention was â€œnot in the cardsâ€ at the moment. The different approaches have created an appearance of significant tension between Trudeau and Ottawa police.â€œThis is a national issue, not an Ottawa issue,â€ Sloly told city councillors on Wednesday. â€œI am increasingly concerned there is no policing solution to this.â€Trudeau also appeared to have lost support from the left, which has grown increasingly frustrated with the fact that the protests not only appear not to be waning, but have expanded into other cities such as Montreal, Toronto, and Vancouver.â€œWhere is the Prime Minister? Has he got nothing? What is he doing about this?â€ a column in theÂ Globe and Mail national newspaperÂ askedÂ on Tuesday.Radical leftist New Democratic Party leader Jagmeet Singh took the lead this week in criticizing Trudeau from the left, asserting that the prime minister has â€œnot been visibleâ€ and calling an emergency Parliament meeting to address the protests in the absence of any action by Trudeau. Trudeau attended the emergency meeting, where lawmakers urged him to provide ideas and solutions to end the protests and generally quell public unrest.Simon Kent contributed to this reporting.Follow Frances Martel onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter.

OTTAWA, Ontario (AP) â€” Canadian lawmakers expressed increasing worry Tuesday about the economic effects of disruptive demonstrations after the busiest border crossing between the U.S. and Canada became partially blocked by truckers protesting vaccine mandates and other COVID-19 restrictions.Ontario Premier Doug Ford called the Ambassador Bridge between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, a â€œvital trade artery.â€ It carries 25 percent of trade between the two countries.â€œSuch blockades will have serious implications on our economy and our supply chain,â€ Canadian Transport Minister Omar Alghabra said in Ottawa, the capital. â€œIâ€™ve already heard from automakers and food grocers. This is really a serious cause for concern.â€Speaking in an emergency debate late Monday in Parliament, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the protesters are â€œtrying to blockade our economy, our democracy,â€ and it has to stop.The daily demonstrations staged by the so-called Freedom Truck Convoy began in Ottawa, where demonstrators have used hundreds of parked trucks to paralyze parts of the capital for more than 10 days. The protests have infuriated people who live around downtown, including neighborhoods near Parliament Hill, the seat of the federal government.Dave Weatherall, a federal civil servant, lives near the truckersâ€™ prime staging area in a city-owned parking lot outside of the downtown core. â€œTheyâ€™re using the lot to terrorize people in Centretown,â€ he said, asking why the city has allowed the convoy to remain parked on its property for free and without intervention.â€œItâ€™s the first time since having kids that Iâ€™ve seriously wondered about the world we brought them into. I always figured they could handle most things the world will throw at them, but this feels different,â€ he said.Demonstrations have spread to locations on or near the Canadian border, including the Ambassador Bridge, where a protest caused long backups and at one point stopped traffic in both directions. The bridge remains blocked on the road to Canada.At a news conference after Trudeau spoke, trucker spokesman Tom Marrazo reiterated that the protesters want to overthrow the government. Marrazo said he is willing to meet with the opposition parties and the nationâ€™s governor general, the representative of Britainâ€™s Queen Elizabeth II as head of state.All three opposition parties technically could join together and defeat the government because Trudeau does not have the majority of seats in Parliament, but that is highly unlikely because the vast majority of lawmakers have condemned the protests.Protesters have also closed another important U.S. Canada border crossing in Coutts, Alberta.â€œThe border at Coutts continues to open and close at the discretion of a group of protesters who believe they are above the law. It has to stop,â€ tweeted Rachel Notley, Albertaâ€™s former premier and current opposition New Democrat leader.Protesters have said they will not leave until all vaccine mandates and COVID-19 restrictions are lifted. They also called for the removal of Trudeauâ€™s government, though it is responsible for few of the restrictive measures, most of which were put in place by provincial governments.FranÃ§ois Laporte, the president of Teamsters Canada, which represents over 55,000 drivers, including 15,000 long-haul truck drivers, said the protests do not represent the industry in which 90% of drivers are vaccinated.The Freedom Convoy â€œand the despicable display of hate lead by the political Right and shamefully encouraged by elected conservative politicians does not reflect the values of Teamsters Canada, nor the vast majority of our members, and in fact has served to de-legitimize the real concerns of most truck drivers today,â€ Laporte said in a statement.Joel Lightbound, a lawmaker for Trudeauâ€™s Liberal Party, rebuked his leader Tuesday for dividing Canadians and said his government needs to create a road map for when coronavirus measures should be lifted.â€œIt is time we stopped dividing people, to stop pitting one part of the population against each other,â€ Lightbound said. â€œI canâ€™t help but notice that both the tone and actions of my government changed drastically on the eve and during the last election campaign. From a positive and unifying approach a decision was made to wedge, to divide and to stigmatize.â€Trudeau continues to take a hard line against the protesters. The prime minister said during Mondayâ€™s Parliament debate that everyone is tired of COVID-19, and that the restrictions will not last forever. He noted that Canada has one of the highest vaccination rates in the world.Meanwhile, the Canadian province of Saskatchewan became the first in the country to announce a plan to lift all COVID-19 restrictions. Saskatchewan officials said they will no longer require COVID-19 vaccine passports starting Monday. The province with a population of almost 1.2 million people is also ending its indoor mask mandate at the end of the month.Conservative Premier Scott Moe said the benefits of providing proof of vaccination to enter businesses such as restaurants no longer outweigh the cost. He said the passport has created deep divisions in the province.â€œI suspect other provinces will do something similar in the next while. I would ask the federal government as well on behalf of all Canadians to continue to revisit the orders that they have in place,â€ Moe said. â€œWe are incumbent to remove them when they have run their course.â€Bruce Heyman, a former U.S. ambassador to Canada, noted that the U.S. and Canada have one of the most significant trading relationships of any two countries in the world, with about $2 billion in daily trade of goods and services. Any blockade of the Ambassador Bridge cannot continue for long as it also critical to the U.S. supply lines, he said.The bridge â€œis also a key access crossing for cross-border jobs such as Canadian nurses in Detroit hospitals and, of course, cross-border access to medical care,â€ Heyman said.____Gillies reported from Toronto.Â

Conservative Party leader Candice Bergen confronted leftist Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday about his repeated use of insults and epithets against individuals who choose not to receive a coronavirus vaccination product, asking if he regretted the role he played in dividing the country.Trudeau made a last-minute appearance in Parliament for Mondayâ€™s emergency session, called by communist New Democratic Party leader Jagmeet Singh, after retreating to an undisclosed location at the start of the protests now known as the â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ which have taken over much of the country. Trudeau announced at the beginning of his retreat that he had tested positive for Chinese coronavirus, necessitating isolation. The largest Freedom Convoy protest is in Ottawa, the nationâ€™s capital, where truckers have flooded the streets and protested government civil rights abuses in the name of public health largely through honking.Trucks parked in downtown Ottawa continue to protest Covid-19 vaccine mandates and restrictions, on February 4, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. (DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)An Ottawa court issued a ban on car horn honking for ten days on Monday in response to the protest.Supporters gather at Parliament Hill for the Freedom Truck Convoy in Ottawa, Canada, on January 29, 2022. (LARS HAGBERG/AFP via Getty Images)Elsewhere in the country, â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests have occurred in multiple places along the U.S.-Canada border and major cities such as Vancouver, Toronto, and Montreal.Protesters assert that they oppose business lockdowns, mask mandates, vaccine mandates, bans on religious gatherings, school restrictions, and any other government civil rights abuses meant to stop the spread of Chinese coronavirus. The protests have been largely peaceful, but leftist politicians, including Trudeau, have repeatedly accused opponents of the restrictions and supporters of the protests generally of unrelated inappropriate views, such as racism.During his remarks on Monday, Trudeau equated the thousands of â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protesters with Nazis, implying falsely that swastikas are common sights at the protests.â€œI look at our country Mr. Speaker, and Iâ€™ve never seen it as divided as it is now under this prime minister,â€ Bergen, who became interim Conservative leader after the ouster of Ed Oâ€™Toole in the aftermath of the protests this month, told Trudeau. â€œWhether its regional lines, whether its ethnic lines, whether itâ€™s peopleâ€™s health care choices â€“ this country is more divided than ever.â€Bergen then asked Trudeau if he took responsibility for his part in creating such a scenario.â€œDoes he regret calling people names who didnâ€™t take the vaccine?â€ Bergen asked of Trudeau. â€œDoes he regret calling people misogynist and racist and just, escalating and poking sticks at them and being so divisive to individual Canadians that he might not disagree with, that he might have thought were wrong?â€â€œDoes he regret that,â€ she concluded, â€œand will he agree to meet with the leaders here, the other opposition leaders and myself, so that we can talk about a solution in a way that heâ€™s described?â€Bergen asserted that the current wave of protests and general political situation was â€œuncharted territoryâ€ for the country.Trudeau did not answer either question, instead insisting that the protests did not represent a significant enough population of Canadians that it merited a response from him.â€œA few people shouting and waving swastikas does not define who Canadians are,â€ Trudeau said, comparing the alleged swastika-wavers to Canadians â€œbeing able to pull a car out of a snowbank for a perfect stranger.â€Trudeau has rejected all calls for him to address the protesters or their concerns. In remarks from his undisclosed location, Trudeau dismissed all people disgruntled with his governmentâ€™s handling of the pandemic as conspiracy theorists.â€œThe concerns expressed by a few people gathered in Ottawa, right now, are not new, not surprising, are heard, but are a continuation of what weâ€™ve unfortunately seen in disinformation and misinformation, online conspiracy theorists, about microchips, about God knows what else that go with tinfoil hats,â€ Trudeau claimed.Trudeau has in the past used the terms â€œracistâ€ and â€œmisogynistâ€ to refer to people who do not receive Chinese coronavirus vaccine product doses.Bergen has, since becoming Conservative leader, attacked Trudeau multiple times for accusing mandate protesters of being racists, noting that Trudeau himself has a long history of wearing blackface â€“ a reality that surfaced in the 2019 election cycle but caused no significant political damage to Trudeau. The prime minister told reporters at the time that he could not guarantee that the multiple photos that had surfaced of him wearing blackface were the only ones, because he had worn blackface on various occasions.Trudeauâ€™s absence during much of the Freedom Convoy protests has outraged the protesters and prompted significant criticism from the protestsâ€™ opponents.â€œI didnâ€™t serve this country to be bullied by a prime minister that ran away like a chicken,â€ Darryl, a retired corporal from the Canadian Army who served in Afghanistan, told Breitbart News from downtown Ottawa on Saturday. â€œWho runs away from their people? Itâ€™s insane. If I was in the army right now, Iâ€™d be contemplating leaving just because our leadership, our military, our country, will have no credibility because of him [Trudeau].â€Media commenters who have written in columns of their opposition to the convoy also blamed Trudeau in various articles this week for the protestsâ€™ prolonged existence, as he has done nothing to address them.Follow Frances Martel onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter.

Truckers traveled from Anchorage to Eagle River, Alaska, over the weekend in support of a massive truck convoy in Ottawa, Canada, to protest coronavirus vaccine mandates in order to conduct cross-border business.More than 100 truck drivers took part in the Alaskan convoy,Â the Anchorage Daily News reported.Â â€œTruck drivers and other service providers since Jan. 15 can only enter Canada if they are fully vaccinated,â€ the Associated Press reported. â€œA week later, the U.S. required vaccinations from essential non-resident travelers.â€â€œWe have to have the shot stamps on our medical cards in order to go out of state, and we donâ€™t want them,â€ Jeremy Speldrich, a truck driver with GMG General, Inc. of Anchorage,â€ said in the AP report. â€œMandates should be our choice, whether you want the shots or not.â€AP reported that a second convoy of truckers drove from Eagle River north to the Wasilla area in a show of support of their northern brothers. And similar events were reported in Fairbanks and late last month in Juneau.Fox News also reported on the â€œAlaska Freedom Convoyâ€ in support of the Canadian â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ which is entering its second week.Anchorage Assembly member Jamie Allard organized the U.S. protest, according to Fox News.Â â€œWe want to support our truckers,â€ Allard told KTUU. â€œWithout them, weâ€™re not getting our supply. We need to get our supplies here. People need to be recognized for everything weâ€™re doing here in our city.â€â€œWe are taking part in the Freedom Convoy standing in solidarity with truckers in Canada and really across North America. We stand for their freedom to choose,â€ Kelly Tshibaka said in a video posted Sunday from the cab of a truck. Tshibaka, who was endorsed by former President Donald Trump, is challenging Alaska Republican Lisa Murkowski in the 2022 midterms for the incumbentâ€™s Senate seat.â€œWe also stand with them as they fight for their jobs, their families, and their abilities to take care of their communities. This is really about freedom,â€ she continued. â€œFreedom from people who want to be tyrants and dictate what we put into our bodies. We are against mandates from our political leaders. Political leaders shouldnâ€™t push their way into the patient-provider relationship.â€â€œThatâ€™s how much we support freedom in Alaska,â€ Tshibaka said.Follow Penny Starr on Twitter

Tow truck companies, contracted by theÂ City of Ottawa, are refusing all of the requests to take heavy vehicles associated with the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ from theÂ downtown area, according toÂ city manager Steve Kanellakos who told reporters on Monday.TheÂ top city official explained that all of the tow truckÂ operators from theÂ list of companies the city typically uses to provide tow servicesÂ have unilaterally said â€œnoâ€ to any request. Global News reported that the demonstrations are headed into the second week of protest.â€œWeâ€™ve contacted them all and theyâ€™re all refusing â€¦ to provide heavy tow truck work,â€ Kanellakos said in a press conference. However, he explained that the tow truckÂ operators are still doingÂ â€œlightâ€ work, notÂ heavy trucks and larger vehicles.â€œMany of them or most of them donâ€™t want to do the work, especially the heavy tow truck work, because they rely on the heavy truck industry for their livelihood and they donâ€™t want to damage that part of their business,â€ Kanellakos explained.The cityâ€™s mayor, Jim Watson, has reportedly been in touch and asked for resources from city officials inÂ Toronto, Brampton, and other Ontario cities, according toÂ Kanellakos. He also explained that the problems removing the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ are happening all over and not â€œan Ottawa-only problem.â€Local police Deputy Chief Steve Bell, not willing to share the specifics, said that the police are trying to findÂ â€œcreative solutionsâ€ to removeÂ demonstrators since they do not have anyÂ cooperation from tow truck companies.â€œWe are coming towards a position where weâ€™re not going to let the tow truck operators, and the ability to tow those vehicles out of there, be an obstacle to ending whatâ€™s occurring,â€ Bell said.The top city officials noted that theÂ city is reviewing its contract with the tow truck operators in order to seeÂ â€œwhat actions we can take to deal with this unprecedented situation.â€Jacob Bliss is a reporter for Breitbart News. You can follow him on Twitter.

Supporters of Canadaâ€™s anti-mandate, trucker-led Freedom Convoy movement shut down traffic on the Ambassador Bridge on Monday. Located between Windsor, Ontario, and Detroit, Michigan, the bridge is part of the busiest border crossing between Canada and the United States.Protesters blocked the Ambassador Bridge exit onto Huron Church Road in Windsor on Monday, obliging the police to recommend an alternate route for motorists. The resulting traffic jam spread through Windsor and eventually reached across the border into the United States.Reporting from Windsor, Ontario. This is is the backup on the Canadian side trying to cross the Ambassador Bridge into Detroit. The truckersâ€™ protest has everything at a standstill. @globalnewsto @GlobalNational pic.twitter.com/ZETZjtHMl1â€” Ã¡ â€™ Global News (@ConsumerSOS) February 8, 2022The Ambassador Bridge was closed entirely for part of Monday night and Tuesday morning. Police advised motorists, particularly those driving commercial vehicles, to reroute to an entirely different bridge, the Bluewater in Sarnia, if they needed to cross the U.S. border.Â A tunnel from Windsor to Detroit was also recommended as an alternative by the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA).This is the scene at the Ambassador bridge crossing. Canada bound traffic stopped by protesters â€“ seems like US bound is still flowing. @CBCWindsor pic.twitter.com/e5OhADRX0Dâ€” Jacob Barker (@JacobBarkerCBC) February 7, 2022It's Day 2 of the anti-mandate demonstration in Windsor. There is no incoming traffic from the U.S. on the Ambassador Bridge and trucks are lined up for several kilometres to cross into Michigan. pic.twitter.com/cln0q3F8fkâ€” Dan Janisse (@winstarjanisse) February 8, 2022Traffic was still reportedly slow and partially blocked on Tuesday, prompting a statement from the Detroit International Bridge Company, owners of the Ambassador Bridge.â€œInternational commerce needs to resume,â€ said company chairman Matt Moroun.Â â€œThe Ambassador Bridge and the Moroun family sympathize with truck drivers and those caught up in this blockade. We recognize truck drivers are essential workers that work hard to deliver necessities to all of us and that the Canadian government has done a tremendous job with vaccine rates,â€ Moroun said.â€œThe Ambassador Bridge has a solemn obligation to facilitate safe and efficient international trade and travel. We encourage the appropriate officials to take prompt action to alleviate the situation as quickly as possible in a manner that reflects mutual respect,â€ he concluded.Windsor-Essex Regional Chamber of Commerce CEO Rakesh Naidu was less sympathetic to the protesters.â€œMany businesses have been through so much in the last two years. This couldnâ€™t come at a worse time. To constrict the border like this will impact everyone not just in Windsor, but Ontario and Canada. You have thousands of businesses that rely on the border and trade coming through. You have inventory based on just-in-time delivery,â€ Naidu told the Windsor Star on Tuesday.â€œAny disruption of supply can lead to shifts being canceled and if it continues, closing operations,â€ Naidu cautioned. â€œAll of that doesnâ€™t just impact the businesses in all the different sectors, but consumers like you and me. This is not just manufacturing, but goods we all consume as well, like fresh produce, or chemicals and fuel that we need.â€Writing at the Toronto Sun on Tuesday, columnist Brian Lilley saw the Ambassador Bridge protest as a possible turning point in the Freedom Convoy saga, because Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has no good answer to it.â€œWill Trudeau dismiss these people as racists like he does everyone else who disagrees with him? Thatâ€™s what Trudeau has done in the past with several people or groups opposed to him and it seems to be the only response he has to the protests in Ottawa,â€ Lilley wrote.â€œThis is all about politics and Trudeauâ€™s desire to pump up his base of supporters against the protesters, attach the protest movement to Conservatives, and reap the rewards with increased voter support if or when violent confrontation with the police takes place,â€ he charged, contrasting Trudeauâ€™s confrontational and insulting attitude toward Canadian truckers with his support for Indian farm protesters last year.â€œThat single bridge connecting Windsor to Detroit carries 27% of the total two-way trade between Canada and the United States. Yelling racist wonâ€™t fix this problem. Perhaps itâ€™s time for Trudeau to offer the same dialogue to Canadian protesters as he offered to Indian protesters,â€ Lilley concluded.

The White House on Tuesday backed the right of Canadian truckers to protest Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and the overbearing coronavirus restrictions and vaccine mandates.â€œWe of course support as you know the right to freedom of speech and protest,â€ White House press secretary Jen Psaki said during the daily briefing on Tuesday.â€œEveryone can peacefully protest, we fully support that,â€ she added.The White House response differs from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who smeared Freedom Convoy protestors as a â€œfringe minorityâ€ with â€œunacceptable viewsâ€ and described them as racist.The ongoing protests of the Canadian vaccine mandates and coronavirus restrictions shut down traffic on the Ambassador Bridge between Canada and Detroit on Monday, a major trade route with the United States.Psaki, however, downplayed the idea that the congestion was directly related to vaccine requirements, claiming there is â€œzero indicationâ€ that vaccine requirements in various industries cause disruptions.â€œWhile we do see some of these congestions due to protests, itâ€™s clear these disruptions have broadened in scope beyond the vaccine requirement implementation,â€ she said.Psaki defended the idea of vaccine mandates but acknowledged the protests were having an impact.â€œWe know that requirements work,â€ she said. â€œWe have not seen a disruption as it relates to requirements in the industry, where we have seen disruption has been related to these convoys and protests.â€When asked aboutÂ reports of an organization of truckers in the United States protesting vaccine mandates conducting their own protest in Washington, D.C., Psaki deferred to security and law enforcement officials in the administration.

The only people getting injured or have been injured so far are the protesters, the truckers.In Winnipeg on Friday, an anarchist called David Zegarac drove his jeep into four people who were protesting vaccine mandates. Youâ€™re seeing that on the screen right now.Zegarac didnâ€™t stop after hitting the people, he fled. Police shortly, they arrested him. Of course, police are treating the incident like a hit and run. Nothing political. Itâ€™s not domestic terrorism or anything. David Zegarac, his views, they agree with. Heâ€™s a progressive, a true believer. How much is he a true believer?Well, if you look closely, youâ€™ll notice that Zegarac has his mask on driving alone in his car during the assault, prima facie evidence of mental illness, something you see in this country all the time, and it makes you wonder: If youâ€™re driving alone with a mask on, do you pose a danger to pedestrians? Now, they have met the enemy and the enemy, their enemy, is themselves because theyâ€™ve become what they hated. Screw them.Will Joe Scarborough say that to their faces? Probably not.Scarborough is famously tough on young female employees. What would happen if American truck drivers decided theyâ€™d had enough of people like Joe Scarborough and went on strike? What would happen then?Well, this country would stop immediately, no more deliveries of anything. Over time that would mean starvation for people in the cities, but even in the short term, there would be profound suffering in this country.For example, and this is something that too few people outside of television even consider, the worldâ€™s entire supply of Botox is manufactured on the West Coast of Ireland. Thatâ€™s a long way from here. Most of the time, trends start in the United States and they move north to Canada, but this time, the opposite could happen.Follow Jeff Poor on Twitter @jeff_poor

Coronavirus case counts fell 17 percent worldwide over the last week compared to the previous corresponding period, including a 50 percent drop in the United States alone, while deaths globally declined seven percent, the World Health Organization (W.H.O.) announced Tuesday.The weekly epidemiological report from the U.N. health agency outlines the omicron variant is increasingly dominant â€” making up nearly 97 percent of all cases tallied by the international virus-tracking platform known as GISAID. Just over three percent were of the delta variant.The new statistics come as calls grow around the world for an end to mask mandates and compulsory vaccinations, as Breitbart News reported.King Biden's Massive Flip-Flop on Vax Mandates pic.twitter.com/6od5UrsQTbâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) September 10, 2021â€œThe prevalence of the omicron variant has increased globally and is now detected in almost all countries,â€ W.H.O. said. â€œHowever, many of the countries which reported an early rise in the number of cases due to the omicron variant have now reported a decline in the total number of new cases since the beginning of January 2022.â€All told, W.H.O. reported more than 19 million new cases of coronavirus and under 68,000 new deaths during the week from Jan. 31 to Feb. 6. As with all such tallies, experts say such figures are believed to greatly underestimate the real toll.Case counts fell in each of W.H.O.â€™s six regions except its eastern Mediterranean zone, which reported a 36 percent jump, notably with increases in Afghanistan, Iran and Jordan.Municipal workers take part in a demonstration to protest against the coronavirus vaccine mandate, in New York on October 25, 2021. (ED JONES/AFP via Getty Images)The news of the decline in case counts comes as governments around the world look to wind back their restrictions.Australia will soon reopen its borders to vaccinated visitors. Sweden is lifting most pandemic regulations, following in the footsteps of Denmark and Norway.Just this week, the governors of California, Connecticut, Delaware, New Jersey and Oregon said they would end statewide indoor mask mandates, some of which applied to schools and others to public places, the New York Times reports.In Canada the drive for freedom from all coronavirus restrictions has made global headlines.Ottawa Freedom Convoy Supporter Responds to Corporate Media Calling Trucker Protests "White Supremacy" pic.twitter.com/oou5PRNNChâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) February 4, 2022Not every U.S. state is keen to end the restrictions, however.As Breitbart News reported,Â Los Angeles County will retain its indoor mask mandate past the February 15 date set Monday by Gov. Gavin Newsom as the date to end a statewide mandate, according to public health officials in the county.The state will still require unvaccinated people to wear masks indoors after Feb. 15, at the risk of stigmatizing all those who wish to wear masks as a precaution.

(GEOFF ROBINS/AFP via Getty Images)Bellâ€™s warning of â€œconsequencesâ€ for protesters and their supporters comes less than 24-hours afterÂ Ottawa police detained and brutalized a 78-year-old man identified as Gerry Charlebois on Monday for violating the ban imposed that day on honking car horns.They acted as more people against Canada rallied both for their freedom and against left-wing Prime Minister Justin Trudeauâ€™s dismissal of their concerns.Canadian Veteran: I Didn't Serve to Be "Bullied" by PM Who "Ran Way" Like a Chicken pic.twitter.com/qHDkGqnLkbâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) February 8, 2022As Breitbart News reported, police appear in multiple videos twisting the elderly manâ€™s arm around his back and shoving him into the side of a car.The arrest came as part of a broader crack down on a trucker-led protest in Canadaâ€™s capital dubbed the â€œFreedom Convoy.â€Members of the protest demand an end to civil rights abuses by the Canadian government in the name of stopping the spread of Chinese coronavirus, including vaccine and mask mandates and business shutdowns.Protesters block the roadway leaving the Ambassador Bridge border crossing, in Windsor, Ontario, Canada on February 8, 2022. Internationally, while there have been rallies of support in New Zealandâ€™s capital Wellington and Canberra in Australia.The Canadian province of Alberta announced Tuesday some of its coronavirus restrictions â€“ including its controversial vaccine passport â€“ would be lifted from midnight, as Breitbart News reported.

OTTAWA, Ontario â€“ Canadian leftists this week began using war termsÂ  such as â€œoccupation,â€ â€œsiege,â€ and â€œterrorismâ€ to describe the ongoing Freedom Convoy demonstration in Ottawa, alongside calls inviting authorities to consider the use of military intervention to end the protest.During an â€œemergency debateâ€ in the House of Commons on Monday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said demonstrators in Canadaâ€™s capital city â€œare trying to blockade our economy, our democracy, and our fellow citizensâ€™ daily lives.â€ He framed the demonstrations as characterized by Nazi symbolism and confederate flags.â€œThe people of Ottawa donâ€™t deserve to be harassed in their own neighborhoods,â€ he added. â€œThey donâ€™t deserve to be confronted with the inherent violence of a swastika flying on a street corner, or a Confederate flag, or the insults and jeers just because theyâ€™re wearing a mask.â€Minister of Public Safety Marco Mendicino said Ottawans are being â€œheld hostageâ€ by the Freedom Convoy. He accused the demonstration of manifesting widespread criminal intimidation and violence.â€œMany [Ottawans], especially young women, feel unsafe,â€ Mendicino claimed. â€œTheyâ€™ve been blockaded by an angry, loud, intolerant, and often violent crowd. â€¦ Peaceful protests do not make people afraid to leave their homes, and this convoy has done that, and in doing so it has crossed the line.â€He described the demonstration as lawless. He said, â€œWe are doing what we can to end this convoy and reestablish law and order in Ottawa.â€Â Mendicino said swastikas and Confederate flags were common among Freedom Convoy demonstrators.â€œThe flying of Confederate flags [and] the demonstration of swastikasÂ â€¦ are not isolated incidents,â€ he alleged. â€œIt has been rampant.â€â€œThe people of Ottawa are under siege,â€ communist New Democratic Party Leader Jagmeet Singh said during the House of Commons debate. HeÂ praised Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for considering the use of â€œadditional resourcesâ€ to â€œput an end to the ongoing occupation in Ottawaâ€™s downtown core.â€I want to thank @JustinTrudeau @BillBlair @marcomendicino for the constructive discussions this afternoon on the next steps we need to take together, including the commitment of additional resources, to put an end to the ongoing occupation in Ottawaâ€™s downtown core.â€” Jim Watson (@JimWatsonOttawa) February 8, 2022WatsonÂ described the sight of children playing in bouncy castles amid the Freedom Convoy demonstration as â€œdisturbingâ€ in an interview with CTV News on Sunday.Diane Deans, an Ottawa city councilor who announced her bid for the cityâ€™s mayorship, labeled the Freedom Convoy a â€œnationwide insurrectionâ€ and â€œthreat to our democracyâ€ during a â€œspecial meetingâ€ conducted via Zoom with local authorities on Saturday.
