Canadaâ€™s Freedom Convoy trucker protest against vaccine mandates continued on Tuesday as mandates, vaccine passport systems, and other coronavirus restrictions began falling in provinces across the country â€“ including Alberta, Saskatchewan, Quebec, and Prince Edward Island.Premier Jason Kenney of Alberta, scene of a vigorous Freedom Convoy protest at a vital border crossing with the United States, announced the end of its vaccine passports on Tuesday in a remorseful news conference that described pandemic restrictions as a source of â€œterrible division.â€â€œNow is the time to begin learning to live with [Chinese coronavirus],â€ Kenney said on Tuesday. â€œWe cannot remain at a heightened state of emergency forever. We have to begin to heal.â€â€œThe threat of Covid-19 [Chinese coronavirus] to public health no longer outweighs the hugely damaging impact of health restrictions. We are well positioned to live with this virus,â€ he said, citing reduced hospitalization and encouraging wastewater analysis as reasons to begin easing pandemic rules.In truth, the number of hospitalizations in Alberta is fairly steady, as the Globe and Mail pointed out â€“ with some implied skepticism about Kenneyâ€™s insistence that the massive Freedom Convoy protests had nothing to do with his sudden realization that pandemic restrictions have outlived their usefulness.Hundreds of truck drivers and their supporters block the streets of downtown Ottawa as part of a convoy of protesters against COVID-19 mandates in Canada on February 09, 2022 in Ottawa, Ontario. (Spencer Platt/Getty Images)â€œThe program is no longer serving a useful and compelling purpose,â€ Kenney said of vaccine passports. â€œI could not stand in front of Albertans tonight and justify a continuation of a program that has done its job.â€â€œNone of that has to do anything with a few trucks parked at the Coutts border crossing,â€ he added.Supporters gather at Parliament Hill for the Freedom Truck Convoy in Ottawa, Canada, on January 29, 2022. (LARS HAGBERG/AFP via Getty Images)Kenney said restrictions would be lifted in three stages, beginning with the termination of vaccine passports at midnight and the end of pandemic policies in schools, including the odious mask mandate on young children.â€œIt is time to let kids be kids,â€ Kenney said.Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe said his own provinceâ€™s vaccine passport system would be eliminated on Valentineâ€™s Day, while indoor masking requirements would be lifted at the end of February.Protestors of the vaccine mandates implemented by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau walk near Parliament Hill on February 5, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images)Like Kenney, Moe acknowledged the vaccine passports created â€œdeep divisionsâ€ in society. He said enforcing the passport system was no longer worth the social cost now that the dangerous delta variant has given way to the more contagious, but less lethal, omicron variant â€“ something that actually happened in December at the latest.The Globe and Mail reported Moeâ€™s declaration of eased restrictions came with a plea for social unity, although he also insisted the protest movement had nothing to do with his decision:â€œIt is time for us also to heal the divisions in our communities over vaccinations,â€ Mr. Moe said. He asked residents not to judge each other over vaccination status or turn on those who wear masks after that requirement expires at the end of February.â€œDonâ€™t lose a friend to COVID,â€ he said.Mr. Moe said people from across the province influenced his governmentâ€™s policy shift, but not specifically the convoys of protesters. He said his MLAs listened to constituents and their changing attitudes. â€œUltimately, you blend that with the science that we have.â€Premier Dennis King announced that Prince Edward Island will begin easing its pandemic restrictions on February 17, but will not finish lifting mask requirements and limits on public gatherings until April 7. Even then, King said restrictions could remain in place indefinitely for â€œhigh-riskâ€ facilities like hospitals and nursing homes.â€œThis is not a declaration that Covid is over, or that Covid will disappear, or that we are standing here saying mission accomplished. Covid is still with us and it will be with us,â€ King warned.â€œToday is a day we cautiously look forward with hope and optimism,â€ he said.Quebec Premier Francois Legault acknowledged public frustration with coronavirus restrictions and said their time was coming to an end, although he insisted they were necessary over the past two years.â€œThe population is fed up. Iâ€™m fed up. Weâ€™re all fed up. But the reason we resisted until today was because there was too much risk. Right now, we can take a calculated risk and finally turn the page,â€ he said.Like his fellow provincial executives in Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Prince Edward Island, Legault insisted the Freedom Convoy had nothing to do with the immutable science of Chinese coronavirus changing overnight, but at least he offered his spin with a sense of humor.â€œIf they want to take credit and not come back in two weeks, I wouldnâ€™t be opposed to that,â€ he wisecracked about Quebec City protesters, who held a demonstration last weekend and pledged to return in two weeks if conditions have not improved.Â The Globe and Mail quoted communications professor David Taras of Calgaryâ€™s Mount Royal University predicting Canadian politicians would probably get away with pretending they coincidentally decided to begin lifting restrictions just as the Freedom Convoy protests peaked, because the public is weary of the endless pandemic and looking for an offramp.â€œTheyâ€™re not looking weak. I think the public exhaustion is now working in favor of the government,â€ Taras said â€“ a prognosis that might offer a ray of hope to nervous Democrats south of the Canadian border as they, too, abruptly discover science coincidentally changed at the exact moment their poll numbers hit rock bottom.

Canadian leftists and corporate media this week have begun denouncing the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ â€“ a trucker-led protest against civil rights abuses in the name of the Chinese coronavirus pandemic â€“ by associating it with former President Donald Trump, the â€œalt-right,â€ and the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot.In reality, the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ movement refers to a series of protests in which truckers â€“ who have been most onerously affected by interprovincial vaccine mandates and other coronavirus-related edicts â€“ have used their vehicles to occupy cities and border crossings. The largest such protest is in Ottawa, the national capital, where thousands have convened to demand the federal government lift mandates. The main form of protest in Ottawa has been honking truck horns, resulting in a court injunction banning the use of car horns.Despite the overwhelming numbers of protesters in Ottawa â€“ and Toronto, Quebec, Vancouver, and crossings all along the southern border â€“ police have reported very few incidents of violence, some of them directly caused by police.The Canadian left has begun to accuse the domestic movement of being associated with President Trump, disregarding his effusive campaign for vaccination and his role in implementing the first wave of lockdowns in the United States, as well as elevating celebrity doctor Anthony Fauci to household name status. At the top of the list of accusers is the head of the radical leftist New Democratic Party, Fidel Castro sympathizer Jagmeet Singh, who has attributed the popularity and success of the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ to â€œTrumpismâ€ and â€œforeign actors,â€ without evidence.â€œThe spread of Trumpism into Canada must be stopped,â€ Singh declared on Twitter, encouraging followers to join his campaign to â€œshut down U.S. interferenceâ€ within the convoy. His partyâ€™s website blames, among others, Trump, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), Fox News, and the â€œalt-rightâ€ â€“ a term popularized in the 2016 election and largely out of use to describe any political group today â€“ for Canadian anti-mandate protests.â€œIt is time for national leadership â€“ the federal government must contact the US administration to shut down funding coming from the US,â€ the New Democrats declare. â€œAdd your name to protect our democracy by shutting down the flow of foreign funding coming from the US.â€Writing at theÂ Globe and Mail on Tuesday, columnist Gary Mason adopted Singhâ€™s terminology and branded the Canadian civil rights protesters with the 2016 terminology â€œalt-right,â€ describing the entire concept of â€œfreedomâ€ as having been hijacked by extremists and no longer legitimate.â€œFreedom, as an ideology, has been appropriated by the Make America Great Again (MAGA) wing of the U.S. Republican party. There is a strong MAGA fan base in this country, apparently with prominent supporters such as Candice Bergen, the new interim leader of the federal Conservative Party of Canada,â€ Mason lamented. â€œUndated photos circulating on social media appear to show Ms. Bergen sporting a camouflage MAGA hat.â€â€œThe word â€˜freedomâ€™ could be found on most signs being touted by the protesters. For many, itâ€™s a word that has become code for white-identity politics and the far-rightâ€™s weapon of choice in the culture wars,â€ Mason asserted.A similar column published last week by theÂ Edmonton Journal compared the protests to the January 6 incident, which had no ties to the Chinese coronavirus pandemic.â€œIt became clear early on that the convoyâ€™s leadership was a partisan mix of anti-science, anti-vax, libertarian cranks, with a wholly overblown sense of their importance,â€ the column read. â€œCalling for a Jan. 6-like overthrow of the Canadian government, issuing pretentious twaddle in the form of demands, and carrying around Nazi or Confederate flags will not â€” fortunately â€” win the hearts and minds of most Canadians.â€TheÂ Washington Post also seized on calling the trucker convoys â€œTrumpianâ€ on Tuesday.â€œCanada is becoming an unlikely symbol of the radicalization of the anti-vaccination movement in the West that shares more than a few similarities with the militancy of Trump Republicans,â€ the Jeff Bezos-owned publication claimed. â€œParallels to the Jan. 6 insurrection may be limited in Ottawa â€” protesters are not knocking down the doors of Parliament. But anti-government slogans flooding Ottawaâ€™s streets suggest similar grievances, even as their trucks serve as a flashback to the Trump caravans that menaced U.S. highways during the 2020 campaign.â€The comparisons omit Trumpâ€™s own history with coronavirus mandates, initially imposing the â€œtwo weeks to slow the spreadâ€ lockdown campaign and extending restrictions beyond Easter 2020 when he hadÂ promised the American people they would end. As president, Trump held daily televised events with Fauci and other public health officials, granting them a nearly unparalleled platform to impose their views, which align with the opponents of the â€œFreedom Convoy.â€ Trump eventually spoke out against vaccine and mask mandates as they became politically unpalatable among conservatives.More recently,Â Trump claimed that he had personally â€œdeveloped the vaccine,â€ boasted about receiving a booster vaccine product dose, and has enthusiastically urged supporters to do the same.

Leftist Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faced jeers and insults in Parliament on Tuesday as he once again faced questions regarding his derision towards citizens who oppose civil rights violations tied to the Chinese coronavirus pandemic.Trudeau had a contentious week in Parliament after vanishing from the public eye to an undisclosed site in late January, allegedly to recover from a Chinese coronavirus infection himself. He returned on Monday to an emergency session discussing the â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ a series of protests led by truckers demanding an end to vaccine and mask mandates, business lockdowns, and travel restrictions that the Trudeau government has imposed in an attempt to contain the pandemic.The largest iteration of the convoy is currently in downtown Ottawa, not far from Parliament. The city has been flooded by trucks for nearly two weeks and attracted thousands of protesters â€“ most of whom, according to police, have been peaceful. Reports on the ground have revealed the development of a community among the protesters including distribution of free food, drinks, and other supplies and a generally positive party atmosphere, save for instances of police brutality.Trudeau has repeatedly insisted he would not listen to any calls for lifting the mandates and restoring normal life to Canada. He has accused the protesters of racism and misogyny and equated them with Nazis in his statements in Parliament on Monday.The next day, he once again faced calls to meet with opposition leaders and bring an end to the onerous mandate regime currently in place. The interim leader of the Conservative Party, Candice Bergen, asked Trudeau if he would consider ending restrictions once again.â€œThis cannot be a slow and dragged out process simply because of the prime ministerâ€™s ego, pride, or denial,â€ Bergen said. â€œCanadians are too tired. Canadians need hope. So will the prime minister follow the science, follow the evidence, end the restrictions, end the mandates?â€OTTAWA, ON â€“ FEBRUARY 05: A â€œWhereâ€™s Trudeauâ€ sign is seen near Parliament Hill on February 5, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. Truckers continue their rally over the weekend near Parliament Hill in hopes of pressuring the government to roll back COVID-19 public health regulations and mandates. (Photo by Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images)Trudeau did not answer the question, instead asserting, amid heckling and jeers, â€œweâ€™re going to continue to follow the science, weâ€™re going to continue to have Canadiansâ€™ backs, weâ€™re going to continue to protect peopleâ€™s lives.â€Bergen again asked him to answer the question, but upon his second attempt, the jeering became so loud that he stopped abruptly and sat down to wait for it to end. Amid the shouting, one voice could be heard saying, â€œLet him answer, heâ€™s not good at it!â€Speaker of the House of Commons Anthony Rota admonished the chamber and confirmed that the shouting was, indeed, jeers.â€œThe honorable leader of the opposition asked a question and sheâ€™s trying to hear, but she canâ€™t hear it above all the heckling and shouting thatâ€™s going on,â€ Rota scolded.The speaker did not succeed in silencing the shouting entirely but diminished it enough for Trudeau to finish his response, which was nearly identical to his first statement.Trudeau and Bergen have engaged in several testy exchanges since she assumed the leadership of the Conservative Party following the ouster of predecessor Erin Oâ€™Toole last week. On Monday, Bergen pressed Trudeau for an apology for his invective against those who choose not to receive a Chinese coronavirus vaccine.â€œDoes he regret calling people names who didnâ€™t take the vaccine?â€ Bergen asked of Trudeau. â€œDoes he regret calling people misogynist and racist and just, escalating and poking sticks at them and being so divisive to individual Canadians that he might not disagree with, that he might have thought were wrong?â€Trudeau responded by associating the protesters with Nazis.A protester holds up a sign condemning the vaccine mandates introduced by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Quebec Premier FranÃ§ois Legault. (Photo by Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images)â€œA few people shouting and waving swastikas does not define who Canadians are,â€ Trudeau said.The prime minister has repeatedly referred to protesters, and any individual who does not agree with mandates regardless of participation, in similar terms. In remarks from his undisclosed location last week, Trudeau accused the protesters of wearing â€œtinfoil hatsâ€ and compared them unfavorably to the violent riots fueled by the â€œBlack Lives Matterâ€ movement in 2020. Trudeau met with members of that movement and kneeled before them at the time.â€œI have attended protests and rallies in the past when I agree with the goals, [and] when I supported the people expressing their concerns and their issues. Black Lives Matter is an excellent example of that,â€ Trudeau told reporters. â€œBut I have also chosen to not go anywhere near protests that have expressed hateful rhetoric, violence towards fellow citizens.â€â€œThe concerns expressed by a few people gathered in Ottawa, right now, are not new, not surprising, are heard, but are a continuation of what weâ€™ve unfortunately seen in disinformation and misinformation,â€ Trudeau asserted, equating demonstratorsâ€™ concerns with â€œonline conspiracy theorists, about microchips, about God knows what else that go with tinfoil hats.â€Trudeauâ€™s long absence amid what opponents of the protest movement have called a crisis and occupation has prompted criticism of the prime minister from his left, accusing him of leaving a â€œleadership voidâ€ that has allowed the protests to grow.Follow Frances Martel onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter.

OTTAWA, Ontario â€“ Canadian leftists this week began using war termsÂ  such as â€œoccupation,â€ â€œsiege,â€ and â€œterrorismâ€ to describe the ongoing Freedom Convoy demonstration in Ottawa, alongside calls inviting authorities to consider the use of military intervention to end the protest.During an â€œemergency debateâ€ in the House of Commons on Monday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said demonstrators in Canadaâ€™s capital city â€œare trying to blockade our economy, our democracy, and our fellow citizensâ€™ daily lives.â€ He framed the demonstrations as characterized by Nazi symbolism and confederate flags.â€œThe people of Ottawa donâ€™t deserve to be harassed in their own neighborhoods,â€ he added. â€œThey donâ€™t deserve to be confronted with the inherent violence of a swastika flying on a street corner, or a Confederate flag, or the insults and jeers just because theyâ€™re wearing a mask.â€Minister of Public Safety Marco Mendicino said Ottawans are being â€œheld hostageâ€ by the Freedom Convoy. He accused the demonstration of manifesting widespread criminal intimidation and violence.â€œMany [Ottawans], especially young women, feel unsafe,â€ Mendicino claimed. â€œTheyâ€™ve been blockaded by an angry, loud, intolerant, and often violent crowd. â€¦ Peaceful protests do not make people afraid to leave their homes, and this convoy has done that, and in doing so it has crossed the line.â€He described the demonstration as lawless. He said, â€œWe are doing what we can to end this convoy and reestablish law and order in Ottawa.â€Â Mendicino said swastikas and Confederate flags were common among Freedom Convoy demonstrators.â€œThe flying of Confederate flags [and] the demonstration of swastikasÂ â€¦ are not isolated incidents,â€ he alleged. â€œIt has been rampant.â€â€œThe people of Ottawa are under siege,â€ communist New Democratic Party Leader Jagmeet Singh said during the House of Commons debate. He added, â€œThis convoy protest is not a peaceful protest.â€ He described the demonstration as a display of â€œlawlessness, â€œmob rule,â€ and â€œoccupation.â€ He accused demonstrators ofÂ â€œharassingâ€ Ottawans.â€œThe convoyâ€™s been about hateful symbols,â€ he claimed, â€œlike a Nazi flag and the Confederate flag.â€Ottawa Mayor Jim WatsonÂ has publicly used the terms â€œoccupyâ€ and â€œoccupationâ€ dozens of times across the duration of the protest. HeÂ praised Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for considering the use of â€œadditional resourcesâ€ to â€œput an end to the ongoing occupation in Ottawaâ€™s downtown core.â€I want to thank @JustinTrudeau @BillBlair @marcomendicino for the constructive discussions this afternoon on the next steps we need to take together, including the commitment of additional resources, to put an end to the ongoing occupation in Ottawaâ€™s downtown core.â€” Jim Watson (@JimWatsonOttawa) February 8, 2022WatsonÂ described the sight of children playing in bouncy castles amid the Freedom Convoy demonstration as â€œdisturbingâ€ in an interview with CTV News on Sunday.Diane Deans, an Ottawa city councilor who announced her bid for the cityâ€™s mayorship, labeled the Freedom Convoy a â€œnationwide insurrectionâ€ and â€œthreat to our democracyâ€ during a â€œspecial meetingâ€ conducted via Zoom with local authorities on Saturday. She said demonstrators are â€œterrorizingâ€ Ottawa residents.â€œWe cannot allow this kind of terrorism in our community to continue in this way,â€ she remarked.Ottawa city councillor Diane Deans calls the peaceful Freedom Convoy a â€œnationwide insurrectionâ€ and a â€œthreat to our democracy.â€ pic.twitter.com/gr9fiAaD2Oâ€” The Post Millennial (@TPostMillennial) February 6, 2022On Tuesday, Ottawa Deputy Police Chief Steve Bell described the demonstration as an â€œunlawful occupationâ€ during a â€œvirtual press conference.â€ He characterized the protesters as â€œhighly determined and volatile.â€â€œOur message to demonstrators remains the same,â€ he concluded while delivering prepared remarks, â€œdonâ€™t come, and if you do, there will be consequences, including financial consequences for your illegal and unlawful behavior.â€CTV News asked Ottawaâ€™s mayor about a military option to end the protest. â€œWhat options do we have right now?â€ CTVâ€™s Katie Griffin asked. â€œAre you at the point where you have to request the military to come in?â€Many Canadian news media outlets have openly inquired about the use of military personnel in response to the Freedom Convoy. The Toronto Star published an article entitled, â€œCall in the army? Hereâ€™s how the military could end the truckersâ€™ protest.â€ The Globe and Mail similarly considered the use of military forces to end the demonstration in a column entitled, â€œHow Canadian law allows for military assistance in ending the Ottawa occupation.â€The Globe and MailÂ further called the Freedom Convoy â€œseditionâ€ in an op-ed.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) announced Wednesday that his officer has opened an investigation into GoFundMe following theÂ crowdfunding platformâ€™s decision to shut down aÂ fundraising effort aimed at assisting the â€œFreedom Conveyâ€ in Canada.Paxton said that he issued a Civil Investigative Demands (CIDs) to GoFundMe toÂ review possible breaches or violations of the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act (DTPA) afterÂ itÂ closed nearly $10-million fundraising campaign for the â€œFreedom Convoy,â€ which have protested in Ottawa and other major Canadian cities against the countryâ€™s coronavirus vaccine mandates Initially, GoFundMe planned to re-direct the funds to other charities, but opted to refund the donations amid fierce backlash from conservatives.Paxton said in a statement:GoFundMeâ€™s response to an anti-mandate, pro-libertyÂ movementÂ shouldÂ ring alarm bellsÂ toÂ anyone using the donation platform and, more broadly, anyÂ American wanting to protect their constitutional rights. Many Texans donated to this worthy cause.Â I am acting to protect Texas consumers so that they know where their hard-earned money is going,Â rather than allowing GoFundMe to divert money to another cause without the consent of Texas citizens. I will get to the bottom of this deceitful action.Paxton isnâ€™t the only high-profile Texas Republican who has sought clarity onÂ GoFundMeâ€™s decisions regarding the campaign supporting the â€œFreedom Convoy.â€Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) has asked theÂ Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to launch an investigation into the platform for potential wrongdoing.â€œIt is theft on the part of GoFundMe. The Canadian truckers are heroes, patriots, and they are marching for your freedom and for my freedom. Those truck drivers, god bless them, that are defending Canada, are defending America as well. That is courage on display,â€ Cruz told Fox News. â€œI sent a letter to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) asking that the FTC open an investigation into GoFundMe into whether theyâ€™ve committed deceptive trade practices. Because when people gave money, they gave money under the promise it would go to the Freedom Convoy, not to whatever left-wing political ideology GoFundMe and other Silicon Valley companies support.â€

Every tow truck company that has a municipal contract has refused to haul away the Freedom Convoy trucks that have blocked city streets in the Canadian capital for the past two weeks, Ottawa City Manager Steve Kanellakos said Tuesday.Ottawa declared a state of emergency over the protests on Sunday, with Mayor Jim Watson describing the truckers and their supporters as a threat to the â€œsafety and security of residents.â€The state of emergency led to speculation that Ottawa, and perhaps other city governments, might break up the protests by towing the trucks away.Â Commentators with knowledge of the towing industry suggested its drivers might be reluctant to take action against their fellow truckers, and even if they did agree to haul away Freedom Convoy trucks, the process of towing big rigs is far more complex and time-consuming than towing private motor vehicles â€“ especially if the truck driver does not cooperate.Kanellakos said Ottawa has contracts with ten towing companies, covering everything from enforcement of parking regulations to rescuing city vehicles.A person carries a fuel can on Wellington street as demonstrators continue to protest the Covid-19 vaccine mandates implemented by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on February 9, 2022, in Ottawa, Canada. (DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)â€œWeâ€™ve contacted them all and every one, theyâ€™re all refusing as of today to provide heavy tow truck work,â€ he said after briefing the city council on the situation. He added that the towing companies were still providing services for normal-sized vehicles.Kanellakos said the â€œconsensusâ€ among towing companies â€œseems to be that they donâ€™t want to do the work because the heavy truck industry is such a large part of their livelihoods and they donâ€™t want to damage that part of their businesses,â€ as reported by Canadaâ€™s Globe and Mail.Covid-19 mandate protesters block the roadway at the Ambassador Bridge border crossing with the U.S., in Windsor, Ontario, on February 9, 2022. (GEOFF ROBINS/AFP via Getty Images)A towing company CEO told the Globe and Mail he was concerned for the safety of his employees and future of his company if he instructed his drivers to intervene in the protests, because â€œnobody is going to have my back.â€A similar situation exists at the Coutts border crossing in Alberta, which has been blocked by protesting truckers, according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP).â€œFrom the onset of this event, we actively engaged towing companies to assist. Unfortunately, they were unwilling to become involved when it was implied that helping law enforcement with removal would likely damage their livelihoods into the future,â€ said RCMP Deputy Commissioner Curtis Zablocki at a news conference on Tuesday.Zablocki said it would be a severe â€œchallengeâ€ for the RCMP to move protestersâ€™ trucks without the assistance of commercial towing services, since the police do not have access to the â€œheavy equipmentâ€ required. He said the RCMP has nevertheless been able to reduce the number of trucks blocking the Coutts crossing from 250 to about 50.â€œThey need to recognize that this protest is not lawful. Weâ€™re confident that charges will be laid,â€ he said.Ottawa appears to be looking for a new angle to use against the Freedom Convoy truckers, as the Canadian Press on Tuesday quoted Deputy Police Chief Steve Bell noticing that â€œa quarter of the 418 trucks still camped out in the cityâ€™s downtown have children in them.â€â€œWeâ€™re concerned about access to sanitation, the ability to shower,â€ Bell said. â€œThereâ€™s a multitude of concerns. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re raising it and identifying it as something that we need to address. We need to have discussions with our partners and the childrenâ€™s aid society about how we manage moving ahead.â€This burst of concern for the children of protesters is a little difficult to reconcile with the current police strategy of pressuring the truckers to leave by denying them access to fuel, since trucks without fuel cannot run their heaters, and nighttime temperatures in Ottawa are projected to fall below zero over the weekend.The fuel ban is not working well anyway, as the National Post on Tuesday reported hordes of protest supporters are marching around downtown Ottawa brandishing fuel containers that are either empty or filled with water, making it very difficult for the police to determine which containers might actually have fuel in them.After the â€œfuel banâ€ it is now illegal to bring gas cans to the Freedom Convoy Peaceful Protest â€” here is what the streets of Ottawa looked like tonight. God bless these people ğŸ™ğŸ»ğŸ˜‚ pic.twitter.com/kswVn4vtVSâ€” Benny (@bennyjohnson) February 9, 2022â€œIt does provide a layer of logistical complexity to us,â€ Deputy Police Chief Bell admitted.At the same press conference, Bell said some of the protesters have removed the wheels from their vehicles, while truckers have employed various methods to â€œimmobilizeâ€ their rigs, making the protest blockades hard to clear.

Canadaâ€™s Freedom Convoy trucker protest against vaccine mandates continued on Tuesday as mandates, vaccine passport systems, and other coronavirus restrictions began falling in provinces across the country â€“ including Alberta, Saskatchewan, Quebec, and Prince Edward Island.Premier Jason Kenney of Alberta, scene of a vigorous Freedom Convoy protest at a vital border crossing with the United States, announced the end of its vaccine passports on Tuesday in a remorseful news conference that described pandemic restrictions as a source of â€œterrible division.â€â€œNow is the time to begin learning to live with [Chinese coronavirus],â€ Kenney said on Tuesday. â€œWe cannot remain at a heightened state of emergency forever. We have to begin to heal.â€â€œThe threat of Covid-19 [Chinese coronavirus] to public health no longer outweighs the hugely damaging impact of health restrictions. We are well positioned to live with this virus,â€ he said, citing reduced hospitalization and encouraging wastewater analysis as reasons to begin easing pandemic rules.In truth, the number of hospitalizations in Alberta is fairly steady, as the Globe and Mail pointed out â€“ with some implied skepticism about Kenneyâ€™s insistence that the massive Freedom Convoy protests had nothing to do with his sudden realization that pandemic restrictions have outlived their usefulness.Hundreds of truck drivers and their supporters block the streets of downtown Ottawa as part of a convoy of protesters against COVID-19 mandates in Canada on February 09, 2022 in Ottawa, Ontario. (Spencer Platt/Getty Images)â€œThe program is no longer serving a useful and compelling purpose,â€ Kenney said of vaccine passports. â€œI could not stand in front of Albertans tonight and justify a continuation of a program that has done its job.â€â€œNone of that has to do anything with a few trucks parked at the Coutts border crossing,â€ he added.Supporters gather at Parliament Hill for the Freedom Truck Convoy in Ottawa, Canada, on January 29, 2022. (LARS HAGBERG/AFP via Getty Images)Kenney said restrictions would be lifted in three stages, beginning with the termination of vaccine passports at midnight and the end of pandemic policies in schools, including the odious mask mandate on young children.â€œIt is time to let kids be kids,â€ Kenney said.Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe said his own provinceâ€™s vaccine passport system would be eliminated on Valentineâ€™s Day, while indoor masking requirements would be lifted at the end of February.Protestors of the vaccine mandates implemented by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau walk near Parliament Hill on February 5, 2022 in Ottawa, Canada. (Minas Panagiotakis/Getty Images)Like Kenney, Moe acknowledged the vaccine passports created â€œdeep divisionsâ€ in society. He said enforcing the passport system was no longer worth the social cost now that the dangerous delta variant has given way to the more contagious, but less lethal, omicron variant â€“ something that actually happened in December at the latest.The Globe and Mail reported Moeâ€™s declaration of eased restrictions came with a plea for social unity, although he also insisted the protest movement had nothing to do with his decision:â€œIt is time for us also to heal the divisions in our communities over vaccinations,â€ Mr. Moe said. He asked residents not to judge each other over vaccination status or turn on those who wear masks after that requirement expires at the end of February.â€œDonâ€™t lose a friend to COVID,â€ he said.Mr. Moe said people from across the province influenced his governmentâ€™s policy shift, but not specifically the convoys of protesters. He said his MLAs listened to constituents and their changing attitudes. â€œUltimately, you blend that with the science that we have.â€Premier Dennis King announced that Prince Edward Island will begin easing its pandemic restrictions on February 17, but will not finish lifting mask requirements and limits on public gatherings until April 7. Even then, King said restrictions could remain in place indefinitely for â€œhigh-riskâ€ facilities like hospitals and nursing homes.â€œThis is not a declaration that Covid is over, or that Covid will disappear, or that we are standing here saying mission accomplished. Covid is still with us and it will be with us,â€ King warned.â€œToday is a day we cautiously look forward with hope and optimism,â€ he said.Quebec Premier Francois Legault acknowledged public frustration with coronavirus restrictions and said their time was coming to an end, although he insisted they were necessary over the past two years.â€œThe population is fed up. Iâ€™m fed up. Weâ€™re all fed up. But the reason we resisted until today was because there was too much risk. Right now, we can take a calculated risk and finally turn the page,â€ he said.Like his fellow provincial executives in Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Prince Edward Island, Legault insisted the Freedom Convoy had nothing to do with the immutable science of Chinese coronavirus changing overnight, but at least he offered his spin with a sense of humor.â€œIf they want to take credit and not come back in two weeks, I wouldnâ€™t be opposed to that,â€ he wisecracked about Quebec City protesters, who held a demonstration last weekend and pledged to return in two weeks if conditions have not improved.Â The Globe and Mail quoted communications professor David Taras of Calgaryâ€™s Mount Royal University predicting Canadian politicians would probably get away with pretending they coincidentally decided to begin lifting restrictions just as the Freedom Convoy protests peaked, because the public is weary of the endless pandemic and looking for an offramp.â€œTheyâ€™re not looking weak. I think the public exhaustion is now working in favor of the government,â€ Taras said â€“ a prognosis that might offer a ray of hope to nervous Democrats south of the Canadian border as they, too, abruptly discover science coincidentally changed at the exact moment their poll numbers hit rock bottom.

Fox News host Geraldo Rivera said Wednesday on FNCâ€™s â€œThe Storyâ€ that the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ truckers in Canada are thugs terrorizing the residents of Ottawa.Rivera said, â€œOne manâ€™s freedom is another manâ€™s oppression. Their behavior has been nothing short of thuggish in Ottawa. They kept people in the neighborhood awake all night, revving their engines, blowing their horns. Theyâ€™ve deprived Ottawa of business, of tens of millions of dollars, now theyâ€™re blockading the international bridges.â€He continued, â€œTheyâ€™re laying off people,Â cutting their shifts short inÂ automotive assembly plantsÂ because they canâ€™t get the partsÂ from Canada to the United States. They used their crowbars toÂ threaten cops who were going toÂ tow their trucks away they wereÂ blocking. They told tow truck drivers thatÂ theyâ€™ll remember them when thisÂ is over, a clear intimidation tactic.Â To give these guys the mantle of freedom fighters is absolutely appallingly naÃ¯ve.â€Rivera added, â€œI understand theÂ frustration about masks and allÂ the rest of it, but to give these folks a passÂ is, I think, very destructive.â€He concluded, â€œWhen you have protestersÂ bringing Confederate flags and Swastikas and to paint them inÂ the same portrait asÂ our Founding Fathers? What the hell is that about? They have been very destructive. Forty percent of Canadaâ€™s trade goes over the Ambassador Bridge that they have blocked. What about the hard-workingÂ people that have gone to workÂ every day during this pandemicÂ and now canâ€™t get to work? Or canâ€™t work because thereâ€™s noÂ parts in their factory to workÂ with? IÂ think that itâ€™s selfish, andÂ it is excessive.â€Follow Pam Key on Twitter @pamkeyNEN

The Ambassador Bridge between Detroit and Ontario, whichÂ closed overnight on Monday and reopened to slow-moving traffic on Tuesday, was once again blocked by protesting Canadian truck drivers on Wednesday. The bridge is part of the busiest and most commercially valuable border crossing between Canada and the United States, so it has become a pivotal scene in the Freedom Convoy saga.The Detroit News quoted growing concern on both sides of the border about the economic impact of the Ambassador Bridge blockade:â€œAny delay or disruption in the supply chain creates problems, not just for agriculture but the state economy,â€ said Chuck Lippstreu, president of the Michigan Agri-Business Association, which represents businesses that support farmers, early in the closure.The Canadian Vehicle Manufacturersâ€™ Association, which represents the Detroit Three automakers, called for an end to the protest, citing its effect on the countryâ€™s economy.â€œAuto production relies on efficient supply chain logistics for delivery of parts, components and vehicles,â€ the association said in a statement Tuesday. â€œPersistent delays at the Ambassador Bridge risk disrupting automotive production that employs tens of thousands of Canadians.â€Overflow traffic is beginning to clog alternate routes like the Blue Water Bridge, where personal and commercial traffic is now backed up for miles, with wait times to cross the bridge exceeding four and a half hours on Wednesday morning:Currently on I-94 E heading toward the Blue Water Bridgeâ€¦Truck traffic is moving at a snailâ€™s pace. Itâ€™s due to the Ambassador Bridge partial closure. Drivers are trying to enter Canada from Port Huron. @FOX2News pic.twitter.com/hHeLH8ZlBlâ€” Brandon Hudson (@BHudTV) February 9, 2022â€œIâ€™ve already heard from automakers and food grocers. This is really a serious cause for concern,â€ Canadian Transport Minister Omar Alghabra told the BBC on Tuesday.â€œThe disruption of the Ambassador Bridge is an attack on the well-being of our citizens and the businesses that employ them. As our economies emerge from the impacts of the pandemic, we cannot allow any group to undermine the cross-border trade that supports families on both sides of the border,â€ a coalition of U.S. and Canadian businesses said in a statement released on Tuesday night.Windsor Mayor Drew Dilkens and Police Chief Pam Mizuno held a press conference on Wednesday in which they said about a hundred protesters are blocking the bridge with 50 to 75 vehicles.â€œYou have a number of people who are on the ground here in the protest group that have outwardly stated that this cause is so passionate for them, they feel such a passion for this particular cause, that theyâ€™re willing to die for it. I think one can appreciate that if you have people that hold that sentiment, the situation can escalate to become very dangerous for police and those members of the public in very short order,â€ Dilkens said.Windsor police officials described the demonstrators as mostly â€œcordialâ€ but determined. Dilkens and Mizuno said additional officers, police vehicles, and intelligence support for the Ambassador Bridge had been requested from the provincial and national governments.â€œAction will have to be taken to open this bridge,â€ a frustrated Dilkens said.â€œIâ€™ll be brutally honest: You are trying to have a rational conversation and not everyone on the ground is a rational actor,â€ he said. â€œPolice are doing what is right by taking a moderate approach, trying to sensibly work through this situation where everyone can walk away, nobody gets hurt, and the bridge can open.â€Windsor police would not discuss their plan to reopen the bridge with reporters, insisting their department â€œrespects the rights of Canadians to exercise their freedom of expression and peacefully assembleâ€ and pledging to maintain â€œopen communicationsâ€ with protest organizers.

Matthew Luloff, an Ottawa City Councilman, told American taxpayer-funded NPR that the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests against coronavirus-related mandates in the city were fueled by â€œmiscreantsâ€ embracing â€œhate symbols,â€ which defies on-the-ground reports showing peaceful demonstrations attracting people of all ages.Luloff said the protest had â€œmorphed into something much uglierâ€ than what eyewitness reports had proven, without offering concrete evidence.Â â€œWhen you say ugly, describe that to me,â€ an NPR host for Morning Edition asked Luloff.â€œSo some of the most well-known radicals in this country have now descended upon the capital,â€ Luloff said, failing to name any.â€œSome of them are calling for violence. Some of them are threatening individual politicians. There have been, you know, threats against life and limb. And itâ€™s incredibly discouraging. Weâ€™ve seen some hate symbols. Weâ€™ve seen flyers distributed that are acutely anti-Semitic,â€ he said.A person holds a sign reading â€œFreedomâ€ as truckers and supporters continue to protest against mandates and restrictions related to Covid-19 vaccines in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on February 5, 2022. (Photo by DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)â€œNow, at the same time, there are people within this group that are demonstrating downtown with legitimate concerns, but you donâ€™t have a productive conversation at the business end of a gun or the grill of a semitruck,â€ Luloff argued.â€œAmong some of the demands by the protesters is that the vaccine mandates end nationwide,â€ the NPR host asked. â€œWill the prime minister [Justin Trudeau] give in to these demands?â€Luloff blamed Trudeauâ€™s intransigence on the issue â€” he has steadfastly refused to meet the protesters or address their concerns in any way â€” on the United States:The prime minister has aligned our vaccination policy with the United States so that cross-border truckers are required to be vaccinated. The United States is our largest trading partner, and it is important that on policy matters like this that we are aligned to ensure the proper flow of goods. And so, essentially, itâ€™s the municipality that is paying for the grievances that these truckers and other miscreants, frankly, have with the federal government.But Breitbart News reporting on the ground in Ottawa painted a much different picture of protesters:News media outlets described a fictional parallel universe divorced from the demonstrationâ€™s reality. The Associated Press framed Saturdayâ€™s demonstration as marred by swastikas, Confederate flags, and desecrations of war memorials without providing any photographic or video evidence. CTV operatives breathlessly tweeted accusations of protesters taking food from homeless shelters, waving swastikas, and â€“ gasp! â€“Â going maskless into a Tim Hortons.[A Breitbart reporter] asked Shanna, who lives near Ottawa and had been to the demonstrations daily since Saturday, to address derisions of protesting Canadians from those in news media and politics.She replied, â€œJust come down. Come down any day â€“ even on the weekends or on a weekday â€“ look around. Youâ€™ll for sure see Canada here. Everybody is here in unity, and thereâ€™s all love. Iâ€™ve been down here five days trying to find this â€˜hate.â€™ I canâ€™t find it.â€Canadaâ€™s Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks with reporters prior to Question Period in the House of Commons on Parliament Hill February 8, 2022, in Ottawa, Canada. (Photo by DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)Also, a Canadian news outlet said police on the scene claim the protest is peaceful:The â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests against COVID-19 vaccination mandates and other public health measures have caused gridlock downtown and major headaches for area residents and business owners.Â But Sloly said Monday that things could be much worse.â€œIt could have led to significant and severe injuries, and it could have led to the loss of life,â€ Police Chief Peter Sloly said at the start of the protest. â€œNone of that has occurred over the last four days.â€â€œNo riots, no injuries, no deaths,â€ Sloly said. â€œThat is a measure of success for any jurisdiction in Canada, and quite frankly anywhere in the world.â€Follow Penny Starr on Twitter.

The head of the Trudeau-funded Canadian Anti-Hate Network (CAHN), spread a picture of an antisemitic flier on social media claiming it to have originated with the Ottawa Freedom Convoy, an anti-mandate protest led by truckers.Bernie Farber, who is listed as the Chair of CAHN on the groupâ€™s website, tweeted on Sunday, stating, â€œTaken by a friend in Ottawa at the Occupation. Apparently in plain sight,â€ captioning a picture of an antisemitic flier.The picture of the flier, however, was not from the Ottawa trucker protests against vaccine passports, vaccine mandates and Wuhan coronavirus restrictions â€“ it was from an unrelated event in Miami, Florida, and firstÂ posted on Twitter on January 23rd. Farber defended the post before ultimately deleting his claims.The failure to fact-check his own claims before going public is particularly concerning given Farber runs an organisation paid by the Canadian government to â€œ[monitor]Â extreme-right groups, report on their activities and file complaints with law enforcementâ€, and which has been the main authorityÂ originating claims the trucker protest is extremist.Wow Bernie, isn't it incredible that the picture your "friend in Ottawa at the Occupation" sent you is identical to the photo posted on Twitter two weeks ago by someone in Miami, right down to the ceramic design in the background? https://t.co/s4Xf3IbFrI pic.twitter.com/OJGEgrariZâ€” Jonathan Kay (@jonkay) February 6, 2022After being confronted over the picture on Twitter, Farber later deleted the tweet and stated, â€œOk for the record a friend from Ottawa told me they saw an antisemitic flyer &sent it to me. I posted it. The photo itself was old and originally from Miami. However, they said they saw the same thing. New Zealand police on Thursday arrested 120 people who were protesting against coronavirus restrictions outside the national parliament.The estimated 120 individuals of all ages arrested were reported to have been attempting to camp in the capital Wellington for a third night, following two days of Freedom Convoy protests where initially over one thousand peopleÂ and multiple vehicles gathered against against New Zealandâ€™s vaccine mandates and coronavirus restrictions.In an effort to deter future protests, police have warned all those arrested willÂ face trespass and obstruction charges alongside prosecution in court.The police had reportedly told the remaining around 150-200 protestors â€“ many of whom had vowed to stay there â€œas long as it takes â€“ that they were trespassing, despite it being common practice for protest groups to rally on the lawn outside the parliament, and police previously having said their presence did â€œnot constitute a trespass notice.â€Police arrest people protesting against coronavirus mandates at Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, Thursday, Feb. 10, 2022. The protest began on Tuesday after more than 1,000 people driving cars and trucks from around the country converged on Parliament in a convoy inspired by protests in Canada. (Mark Mitchell/NZ Herald via AP)Protestors are taken away by police in Wellington, New Zealand, Thursday, Feb. 10, 2022.Â  (Mark Mitchell/NZ Herald via AP)On Thursday morning the police announced over megaphones the protestors would be arrested if they didnâ€™t vacate the grounds,Â ABCÂ reports.Police were then seen to move in on the protestors and begin tearing down tents and arresting attendees, at one moment dragging a naked woman across the floor by her hair â€“ it is unclear why the woman was nude, but other protestors were seen with ripped clothing.Protestors chanted â€œhold the lineâ€, â€œshame on youâ€ and one over a megaphone repeatedly said, â€œkeep the peaceâ€ while protestors struggled with the police.A protestor holds a sign during a protest at Parliament on February 10, 2022 in Wellington, New Zealand. Anti-vaccine mandate protesters were broken up by police after three days of demonstrations outside Parliament. (Photo by Hagen Hopkins/Getty Images)Some attendees also performed the MÄoriÂ haka â€“ a traditional war dance by New Zealandâ€™s indigenous population that was popularised by the New Zealand rugby team known as the â€˜All Blacksâ€™.The Speaker of New Zealandâ€™s Parliament, Trevor Mallard, seemed to have escalated the situation between protestors and the police, despite saying on Wednesday the protest was a police matter, opted to close the parliamentâ€™s grounds in an effort to end the protest and isolate the protestors from reinforcements.Leftist NZ Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern initially supported the freedom convoyâ€™s right to protest saying: â€œPeople often protest on the front lawn of Parliament. It is part of New Zealandâ€, however, Ardern has since U-turned on this policy saying on Thursday they need to â€œmove onâ€ â€“ greenlighting the police to break up the rally.Hordes of vehicles blocked streets around New Zealandâ€™s Parliament on Tuesday, in a protest mirroring others building around the world demanding an end to coronavirus restrictions and vaccine mandates. https://t.co/haqWykV3IFâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) February 8, 2022Wellingtonâ€™s police district commander, Superintendent Corrie Parnell attempted to justify the policeâ€™s actions by saying the protest had started to â€œunfairly impact on the wider publicâ€, despite the physical protest, rather than the vehicular protest being largely self-contained on the parliamentâ€™s lawn.Drivers have also been warned that any remaining vehicles in the parliament area that are blocking roads that arenâ€™t moved will be subject to enforcement action.

Leftist Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau endured a second day of intense heckling, insults, and accusations of prioritizing his political power over the health of citizens on Wednesday in a heated session of Parliament.Trudeau is currently under fire from both the left and right for his handling of the ongoing â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests, which have made their biggest impact in the national capital, Ottawa, but have surfaced in multiple major cities and American border crossings. Instead of prioritizing the health and safety of Canadians, he forced an election,â€ Ellis asserted. â€œThis begs the question â€“ why did the prime minister jeopardize the health of Canadians to save his own job?â€Trudeauâ€™s government is violating Canadiansâ€™ freedoms of speech, expression, assembly, and religion, a demonstrator in Ottawa, ON, told Breitbart News on Wednesday during the Freedom Convoy protest in Canadaâ€™s capital city. https://t.co/9OXyP8TBosâ€” Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) February 5, 2022Trudeauâ€™s answers to both questions were similar, claiming that vaccination was popular and that the election was important to drown out anti-mandate voices. In both instances, shouting and heckling from other lawmakers drowned out parts of Trudeauâ€™s answers.The election, he told Bergen, â€œwas an opportunity for Canadians to weigh in on the path forward for our country, on how to continue to fight this pandemic â€“ and what we saw, unfortunately, from the Conservative Party of Canada was a refusal to step up on vaccinations.â€Similarly, Trudeau chided the Party to Ellis, claiming that it was a disgrace that some Conservative lawmakers had not submitted to vaccine product doses, but not addressing social distancing concerns regarding the election.The prime minister also refused, once again, to answer a direct question on when federal civil rights violations against individuals in an effort to contain the Chinese coronavirus would end.â€œCanada has never been so strong and together as we are now,â€ he replied.Trudeau faced pressure on the left from the head of the New Democratic Party (NDP), communist lawmaker Jagmeet Singh, who has launched a campaign to discredit the â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests as foreign interference by Americans. (DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)Singh has also openly accused Trudeau of being absent in leading the country at a time of significant strife.On Wednesday, Singh asked Trudeau if he would contact American officials to stem the alleged flow of American money to the Canadian protesters, to which Trudeau did not directly answer.â€œWe are working with partners at all levels of government,â€ he answered vaguely.Unlike Singh, Yves-FranÃ§ois Blanchet, the leader of the center-leftÂ Bloc QuÃ©bÃ©cois, accused Trudeau of needlessly inciting division and anger, a common complaint among the Conservatives. Blanchet observed widespread â€œmalaise with the governmentâ€™s handling of the pandemicâ€ that he blamed on a â€œstigmatizing and divisive approachâ€ by Trudeauâ€™s government.â€œIs it the prime minister who made the decision to divide and stigmatize for his own gain?â€ Blanchet asked.A person clears ice and snow in front of the Senate of Canada as demonstrators continue to protest the Covid-19 vaccine mandates implemented by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on February 9, 2022, in Ottawa, Canada. (DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)Trudeau replied that his government â€œa decision to unite Canadians around vaccine mandates.â€That decision did not, apparently, unite the country, as â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protesters opposed to vaccine mandates â€“ and any other restriction or mandate tied to the pandemic â€“ have gone on nationwide for nearly two weeks. Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson told reporters on Thursday he did not see any immediate end to the protests and had no plans to directly intervene.Follow Frances Martel onÂ FacebookÂ andÂ Twitter.

Trucker-led protests against coronavirus restrictions in Canada shut down another US border crossing Thursday, as copycat movements gathered steam overseas and Washington called on its northern neighbor to use federal powers to end the blockades.The border obstructions have already impacted business, with the key Ambassador Bridge linking Ontario and Detroit out of service for several days â€” and major automakers forced to cut back production at several plants as a result.A second crossing in the western province of Alberta has been blocked for days, and on Thursday protesters closed down a third â€” in central Manitoba.Citing supply shortages, Ford said it was forced to slow down production at factories in Canada, while some Stellantis factories in the United States and Canada halted work Wednesday evening, General Motors cancelled several shifts and Toyota said its plants were also hit.In the Canadian capital, police said Thursday they were bringing in reinforcements, issuing more arrests and tickets, and stepping up truck towing operations in a bid to break the impasse that has paralyzed the city.But protesters were hunkering down and taking pride in how their two-week protest has mushroomed into an international movement.â€œYou know itâ€™s really bad if Canadians are coming out full force,â€ said protester Naomi Gilman, noting how her fellow citizens had largely remained quiet â€œfor two long yearsâ€ of Covid restrictions.â€œSo I think that resonates around the world for sure,â€ she told AFP.Addressing reporters outside the House of Commons, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau once again called the blockades â€œunacceptableâ€ and said he was working with authorities across the country to bring them to an end.â€œThis is hurting communities across the country,â€ Trudeau said.Washington stepped up its pressure too, with the White House saying that US Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas â€œcalled his Canadian counterparts, urging them to use federal powers to resolve this situation at our joint border.â€Despite Trudeau and Washington warning the protests pose an economic threat, rallies inspired by the trucker movement have sprung up elsewhere, from New Zealand to France and Belgium.An anti-vaccine protest turned ugly Thursday in Wellington, with police clashing with demonstrators on the grounds of parliament and more than 120 people arrested.In France, thousands inspired by the Canadian truckers planned to converge Friday evening on Paris, with some aiming to move onwards to Brussels.Paris police sought to prevent the demonstration, saying they would ban so-called â€œFreedom Convoysâ€ and would stop roads from being blocked, threatening hefty fines or jail â€” while Belgian authorities vowed similar action.And in the United States, supporters took to social media announcing a â€œPeopleâ€™s Convoyâ€ of truckers and â€œall freedom-loving Americansâ€ to gather east of Los Angeles for a two-day rally beginning March 4 before hitting the road, possibly towards the capital Washington.Canadaâ€™s self-styled â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ began last month in the countryâ€™s west â€” launched in anger at requirements that truckers either be vaccinated, or test and isolate, when crossing the US-Canada border.For two weeks they have occupied the capital Ottawa with loud protests marked by music, honking and banner waving.They have caused significant economic disruption by shutting down the Ambassador suspension bridge â€” a trade corridor used daily by more than 40,000 commuters and tourists, and trucks carrying US$323 million worth of goods on average.Even Trudeauâ€™s political rival, Tory party interim leader Candice Bergen who earlier expressed support for the protesters, urged them Thursday to end their siege.â€œI believe the time has come for you to take down the barricades, stop the disruptive action, and come together,â€ she said from the House of Commons.With blockades dragging on, Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer joined a chorus of industry voices warning of the economic impact â€” saying it was â€œimperativeâ€ that Canadian officials rapidly de-escalate the situation.Presumably eager to stop the movement spreading further domestically, several provinces including Alberta, Quebec and Saskatchewan this week announced a gradual lifting or loosening of Covid-19 restrictions.A court has already ordered the truckers to stop the incessant honking that has upset residents in Ottawa and made sleep difficult.But the atmosphere on the streets of the capital remained one of defiance and celebration. Some 400 vehicles remain camped on Parliament Hill below Trudeauâ€™s offices, against a backdrop of barbecues, campfires and music.Dennis Elgie, a curling ice technician who came from Toronto to join the protest, called the movement â€œfantastic.â€â€œIâ€™ve never seen Canadian pride like this,â€ he told AFP. â€œThis is history.â€

Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson said on Wednesday he has no idea when the Freedom Convoy trucker protests that have clogged the streets of the Canadian capital for the past two weeks will end. He contemptuously described the protesters as â€œliving in a parallel universeâ€ and dismissed their press conferences as absurdist comedy akin to a â€œMonty Python sketchâ€ but revealed no plan for improving the situation.â€œTheyâ€™re living in a parallel universe that just does not make any sense. Theyâ€™re embarrassing themselves. I think they should get on their way; go back to their homes and give back our city to its people,â€ Watson railed against the protesters.Watson said he would not meet with protesters until they leave Ottawa.â€œTheyâ€™ve got to get rid of all their rigs and clean up the mess theyâ€™ve created in our city and give the city back to the residents,â€ he insisted.â€œSome of the press conferences weâ€™ve seen are out of a Monty Python sketch,â€ he scoffed, referring to statements made by protest organizers to the media.The Globe and Mail speculated Watson was mocking Freedom Convoy organizers like Benjamin Dichter, who have demanded audiences with the Governor-General and claimed most rank-and-file police officers support the protest movement.The Canadian newspaper threw in a few details that evidently struck it as Pythonesque, including protesters stringing up laundry between traffic pylons, making arrangements to duck out from the demonstration for Valentineâ€™s Day dates, and setting up bouncy houses for their children.The Freedom Convoy protesters could have responded by comparing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to Monty Pythonâ€™s Brave Sir Robin, but there was no record of them doing so at the time of this writing.The Toronto Star on Wednesday said the federal government is painting the Freedom Convoy protests as a â€œgrave threat to Canadaâ€ but â€œsettling into a back-seat role in the crisis,â€ leaving provincial authorities and city police forces to manage the crisis:â€œTheyâ€™re essentially putting their foot on the throat of all Canadians,â€ said Bill Blair, the former Toronto police chief and federal minister for emergency preparedness, referring to the protests that have spread across the country.Yet despite that graphic assessment, the federal government made clear Wednesday that it is not prepared to invoke emergency powers to take the reins of the crisis, which in Ottawa has dragged on for 13 days as truckers and their supporters occupy the streets around Parliament Hill.â€œAll three orders of government have a responsibility, and thatâ€™s why weâ€™re all working together,â€ Blair said, when asked if the federal government would shift to playing a leading role.Along similar lines, Ontario Premier Doug Ford expected police and border agents to break up the protest blocking the vital Ambassador Bridge border crossing to the United States, through which almost 30 percent of commerce between the two nations flows.â€œThe ongoing illegal occupation and blockade happening in Ontario must stop. The damage this is causing to our economy, to peopleâ€™s jobs and their livelihoods is totally unacceptable. We cannot let this continue,â€ Ford said on Wednesday.In addition to some ominous comments about taking action against the protesters because they are allegedly endangering the children camped with them, Ottawa police said on Wednesday they would begin arresting truckers for committing â€œmischief to propertyâ€ by blocking city streets.Freedom Convoy organizer Chris Barber responded that every trucker arrested would be replaced by â€œthree new driversâ€ and said a call had already gone out for reinforcements.On the subject of child welfare, organizer Benjamin Dichter said many truckers are accustomed to taking their families along on long hauls, and the protest movement has received abundant offers from residents of Ottawa and Quebec to provide beds for demonstrators who need them.

participation in an anti-coronavirus vaccine mandate rally in front of the New Zealand parliament building in Wellington.â€œTwo police officers have been filmed dragging a naked female protester by her hair at Parliament grounds today,â€ the New Zealand Herald reported on February 9.â€œFootage sent to the Herald shows the officers dragging the naked woman from the protest crowd,â€ the newspaper revealed.â€œThe woman is pinned to the ground and handcuffed,â€ the Herald detailed, adding, â€œShe is then partially covered in a white sheet and escorted away.â€The woman was one of 120 people The Biden administration reportedly urged Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to use federal powers to quell the truck blockade that has halted the flow of auto parts on theÂ Ambassador Bridge.For the past four days, the Canadian â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ protests have blocked traffic on the main thoroughfare connecting Windsor, Ontario, to Detroit, forcing auto plants in both countries to either shut down or slow production due to the delay in parts deliveries.â€œThe White House said Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg spoke with their Canadian counterparts and urged them to help resolve the standoff,â€ reported the Associated Press.â€œA federal government official said they are not ruling out any options,â€ AP added. â€œThe official spoke on condition of anonymity as they were not authorized to speak publicly.â€The bridge carries 25 percent of all trade between the United States and Canada; effects of the blockades were immediately felt by automakers and mid-west economies. Per the AP:Ford said its Windsor engine plant reopened Thursday after being shut down on Wednesday because of a lack of parts. But the factory and the companyâ€™s assembly plant in Oakville, Ontario, near Toronto, were operating at reduced capacity, the automaker said.On the U.S. side, GM sent the first shift home two hours early Thursday at its Flint, Michigan, heavy-duty pickup truck plant due to parts shortages. Stellantis cut short the first shift Friday at its Jeep plant in Toledo, Ohio, due to parts shortages.Honda will temporarily stop production on one assembly line during the day shift Friday at its plant in Alliston, Ontario. Itâ€™s because of border delays. U.S. Plants are scheduled to run normally Friday. Toyota said three of its plants in Ontario closed for the rest of the week because of parts shortages, and production also had to be curtailed in Georgetown, Kentucky.Both Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and the Teamsters union have denounced the blockades.â€œItâ€™s hitting paychecks and production lines. That is unacceptable,â€ said Whitmer.Exactly the type of federal powers that Justin Trudeau could employ to stop the blockade was not detailed, though the prime minister has said the military remains off the table for the time being. Local tow truck companies have refused to cooperate with authorities.A person holds a sign reading â€œFreedomâ€ as truckers and supporters continue to protest against mandates and restrictions related to Covid-19 vaccines in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. (Photo by Dave Chan / AFP) (Photo by DAVE CHAN/AFP via Getty Images)Matt Mouroun, chairman of the Detroit International Bridge Company, the owner of the Ambassador Bridge, said the blockadeÂ â€œcannot continue any longerâ€ and outlined three ways for the government to end the protest, according to The Independent:1. End the protest by repealing the mandate and recognising that while the vast majority of truck drivers are vaccinated there are some who for many reasons are choosing not to get vaccinated but deserve to be respected and allowed to do their jobs and serve our countries with dignity.2. Remove the vehicles blocking the Ambassador Bridge so commerce and trade can resume.3. Do nothing and hope this ends on its own: an option that will mostly prolong the blockade, further crippling our economy and putting more jobs at risk.Mouroun hoped that once the conflict came to an end, the United States and Canada can work out an agreement so that the trade thoroughfare does not fall subject to politics again.Trudeau has remained firm in his commitment to continuing the vaccine mandates and coronavirus protocols as several provincial premiers have decided to scale back restrictions.â€œCanadians have the right to protest, to disagree with their government, and to make their voices heard. Weâ€™ll always protect that right,â€ TrudeauÂ tweetedÂ on Tuesday.Â â€œBut letâ€™s be clear: They donâ€™t have the right to blockade our economy, or our democracy, or our fellow citizensâ€™ daily lives. It has to stop.â€Meanwhile, conservative Ontario Premier Doug Ford has moved to cut off funding for the protests through the site GiveSendGo after the crowdfunding site GoFundMe shut down the original account that raised $7.8 million. In response, GiveSendGo tweeted on Thursday:Know this! Canada has absolutely ZERO jurisdiction over how we manage our funds here at GiveSendGo. All funds for EVERY campaign on GiveSendGo flow directly to the recipients of those campaigns, not least of which is The Freedom Convoy campaign.Know this! Canada has absolutely ZERO jurisdiction over how we manage our funds here at GiveSendGo. All funds for EVERY campaign on GiveSendGo flow directly to the recipients of those campaigns, not least of which is The Freedom Convoy campaign.â€” GiveSendGo (@GiveSendGo) February 11, 2022Windsor, Ontario, Mayor Drew Dilkens said during a press conference on Thursday afternoon that he will be seeking an injunction to remove the protesters at Ambassador Bridge. He also said that MichiganÂ Gov. Gretchen Whitmer has offered to provide tow equipment to remove the vehicles.â€œMy message is simple: reopen traffic on the bridge,â€ Whitmer said in a press release. â€œIn Michigan, our economy continues to grow because of our hardworking people and innovative small businesses. Now, that momentum is at risk. Commercial traffic is at a standstill at the Ambassador Bridge and heavily backed up at the Blue Water Bridge.â€

New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman on Friday ripped theÂ Freedom Convoy trucker protests intended to combat coronavirus restrictions.Friedman told CNBCâ€™s â€œSquawk Boxâ€ that the protest was part of â€œa pandemic of the foolish and selfish.â€ He acknowledged the truckers have the right to protest but said it was lacking â€œlogic.â€â€œ[R]ight now, we have a pandemic of the foolish and the selfish,â€ Friedman asserted. â€œYou know, what are the governments asking of these drivers who cross borders back and forth every day is get quarantined â€” get vaccinated, fully vaccinated, or be quarantined. Do it for yourself, do it for your neighbors, most of all, do it for the doctors and nurses who have been completely exhausted after two years of this, so you wonâ€™t be putting additional pressure on them. And so I find all of this, all being done in the name of freedom â€” freedom from who? From Mother Nature? Itâ€™s just nonsense. And weâ€™re so late into this. Itâ€™s so hurtful to their neighbors, to the doctors and nurses, and ultimately to their economies.â€â€œBut, Tom, they do have the right to protest,â€ host Becky Quick replied.â€œSure, you have the right to protest, but you should have at least a logic to your protest,â€ Friedman said. â€œThey have a right to protest, and I have a right to tell them their protest is stupid and selfish.â€Follow Trent BakerÂ on TwitterÂ @MagnifiTrent
